content: In a welcome move, Global Payments (GPN) saw its Relative Strength Rating rise from 70 to 73 on Monday. X When looking for the best stocks to buy and watch, one factor to watch closely is relative price strength.This exclusive rating from Investor's Business Daily tracks market leadership with a 1 (worst) to 99 (best) score. The grade shows how a stock's price performance over the trailing 52 weeks stacks up against all the other stocks in our database. Over 100 years of market history shows that the best stocks typically have an RS Rating north of 80 in the early stages of their moves. See if Global Payments can continue to show renewed price strength and hit that benchmark. Looking For The Best Stocks To Buy And Watch? Start HereGlobal Payments is trying to complete a flat base with a 119.04 buy point. See if the stock can clear the breakout price in heavy volume. While revenue growth fell last quarter from 11% to -14%, the bottom line grew 33%, up from 23% in the prior report. The company holds the No. 11 rank among its peers in the Finance-Card/Payment Processing industry group. Mastercard (MA), WEX (WEX) and Green Dot (GDOT) are among the top 5 highly rated stocks within the group.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. With its next quarterly earnings report set for around May 3, Global Payments (GPN) is currently approximately 5% shy of a 119.04 buy point. The entry is based on a first-stage flat base.X Be aware that buying close to when a stock reports can be risky. You don't know how the stock will report and how the market will react, and you don't have enough time to build a profit cushion. You can reduce your exposure by waiting to see how the company reports and how the market reacts. Looking For The Best Stocks To Buy And Watch? Analysts expect earnings-per-share growth of 29% for the quarter, and 26% growth for the full year. Annual earnings-per-share estimates were recently revised higher. The company has a 94 Composite Rating and holds the No. 7 rank among its peers in the Finance-Card/Payment Processing industry group. If you're looking for stocks that are setting up in a base ahead of their next quarterly report, here's one that fits the bill: Global Payments (GPN). It's expected to release its latest numbers around May 3 and is currently approximately 7% shy of a 119.04 buy point. The current formation is a first-stage flat base.X Keep in mind that jumping into a stock right as it gets ready to report means you likely won't have enough time to build a profit cushion before the release. That leaves you exposed to a sudden downturn if the company disappoints investors with poor numbers and/or weak guidance. You can reduce your exposure by waiting to see how the company reports and how the market reacts. Using an options strategy during earnings season is another way to put yourself in a position to profit, while minimizing the potential downside.See How IBD Helps You Make More Money In StocksWhile EPS growth fell in the company's most recent quarterly report from 29% to 23%, the top line grew 11%, up from 9% in the previous report. Analysts expect EPS growth of 29% for the quarter, and 26% growth for the full year. Earnings-per-share estimates for the full year were recently revised upward. The company has a 94 Composite Rating and earns the No. 9 rank among its peers in the Finance-Card/Payment Processing industry group. Mastercard (MA),  (PAGS) and FleetCor Technologies (FLT) are among the top 5 highly rated stocks within the group.Note: Dates for earnings reports are subject to change. Check the company's website for any updates. Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. On Friday, Global Payments (GPN) got an upgrade for its IBD SmartSelect Composite Rating from 94 to 96. X The revised score means the stock currently tops 96% of all other stocks in terms of key performance metrics and technical strength. Winning stocks often have a 95 or higher grade in the early stages of a new price run. Global Payments is now out of buy range after breaking out from a 105.00 buy point in a flat base. Looking For Winning Stocks? Try This Simple RoutineThe stock sports a 95 EPS Rating, which means its recent quarterly and annual earnings growth tops 95% of all stocks. Its Accumulation/Distribution Rating of A- shows heavy buying by institutional investors over the last 13 weeks. In Q4, the company reported 23% earnings-per-share growth. Top line growth increased 11%, up from 9% in the prior quarter. That marks one quarter of rising revenue gains. Global Payments holds the No. 5 rank among its peers in the Finance-Card/Payment Processing industry group. Mastercard (MA) is the top-ranked stock within the group.RELATED:Which Companies Are Now Outperforming 95% Of All Stocks?

The company is expected to report on Feb. 15. The stock is 1% above a 105.00 buy point from a first-stage flat base.X Keep in mind that buying a stock just before it reports is risky, since an EPS or sales miss could send it sharply lower. You can reduce your exposure by waiting to see the actual numbers and the market's reaction. Looking For The Best Stocks To Buy And Watch? The Relative Strength (RS) Rating for Global Payments (GPN) jumped into a new percentile Monday, with an increase from 76 to 83. X This exclusive rating from Investor's Business Daily identifies share price action with a 1 (worst) to 99 (best) score. The rating shows how a stock's price performance over the last 52 weeks stacks up against all the other stocks in our database. Decades of market research shows that the stocks that go on to make the biggest gains typically have an 80 or higher RS Rating in the early stages of their moves.Looking For The Best Stocks To Buy And Watch? Start HereThe stock, which is on the IBD Big Cap 20 , is within a buy zone after breaking past a 105.00 entry in a flat base. The proper buying range extends to 5% above the initial entry. Once a stock hits that benchmark, it's best to hold off investing and wait for it to set up another buying opportunity.. Earnings growth increased last quarter from 24% to 29%, but sales fell from 14% to 9%. Global Payments holds the No. 8 rank among its peers in the Finance-Card/Payment Processing industry group. If an investor were to glance at MarketSmith's monthly chart of the credit-card stock group, an almost unbroken ascent is the rule.During the bull market, which began in 2009, the payment card and processing group has done very well. The group rose in price in each of the past nine years. The cumulative gain over the nine years is 718%.The Nasdaq and the S&P 500 rose 338% and 196% in the same period, according to MarketSmith data.So, individual investors might want to get some exposure to the credit-card stocks. Three such stocks have appeared recently in the Big Cap 20.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseCincinnati area-based Vantiv completed the acquisition of London-based Worldpay (WP) in January, changing the merged company's name to Worldpay. Earnings are expected to grow 11% this year and 20% in 2019. Revenue growth is pegged at 82% this year and 9% next year.The market capitalization of Worldpay is roughly $25 billion and the company is carving a base with an 85.63 buy point. The stock is 4% off a new high.Georgia-based Fleetcor Technologies (FLT) is far along in a new consolidation. The stock is near a 213.84 buy point.Fleetcor's relative strength line is at a high, which is bullish. The RS line measures a stock's performance vs. the S&P 500. When the RS line hits a high before a breakout, that is especially bullish.Annual earnings grew 23% in 2017, the best gain in three years. Revenue also increased 23%.Fleetcor provides payment solutions to businesses. The company, which has a market cap of about $19 billion, partners with other firms such as Chevron (CVX), Uber and Sem Parar. The latter is a leader in electronic toll payments in Brazil.Global Payments (GPN) grew earnings 26% in 2017, the best gain in the past 12 years. The Street expects another 26% gain this year.The stock is consolidating under its 10-week moving average. Bulls prefer to see a stock consolidate above that key support line.Global has a market cap of about $18 billion.Which of the three stocks is best? If an investor wants one quick test, the RS line at a high gives the nod to Fleetcor.Four stocks in the credit card space have gigantic market caps.Visa (V), Mastercard (MA), PayPal (PYPL) and American Express (AXP) have market caps that are roughly three to 10 times bigger than the three payment stocks in the Big Cap 20.While the big four are not in the Big Cap 20, they deserve attention. Three are forming bases.Visa, Mastercard and American Express each have an RS line at a 52-week high.RELATED:Did Investors Over-React To The Warning On Chips?Why Stocks Build The Base-On-Base PatternWhat Leaders Can Tell You About This Market

Tech issues, multinational giants, small caps: It didn't matter. X The Nasdaq composite fell 0.5% as semiconductor-related stocks were drenched by sellers. Worldpay (WP) on Thursday reported better-than-expected first-quarter earnings. The payments technology stock fell as its in-line outlook appeared to disappoint investors. But payments peer Green Dot (GDOT) was breaking out a day after reporting earnings.Green Dot joins larger payments stocks Visa (V), Mastercard (MA) and Square (SQ) within buy range.Worldpay earned 81 cents a share, up 19%, with revenue soaring 81% to $850.7 million. Those results beat expectations for 77 cents per share and $838 million, respectively. The sales jump followed the merger in January that created Worldpay — the purchase of Worldpay Group by payment processor Vantiv.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseWorldpay sees Q2 EPS of 93-96 cents with revenue of $960 million to $980 million, compared to consensus for 94 cents and $978 million.The company also raised its full-year outlook, but perhaps not enough to excite investors, Nomura-Instinet analyst Dan Dolev suggested in a research note.For the full year, the company expects EPS of $3.71-$3.81 on sales of $3.81 billion to $3.9 billion. That outlook was up from a January forecast of $3.66-$3.76 EPS and revenue of $3.8 billion to $3.89 billion. Analysts had forecast EPS of $3.72 and revenue of $3.872 billion.Worldpay fell 3.25% to 81.74 in the stock market today, backing away from an 85.63 buy point from a flat base. The stock has a Composite Rating of 96, out of a best-possible 99."Given new accounting standards, M&A impact, and lack of pure organic growth disclosures, results are difficult to digest, in our view," Dolev said.Meanwhile, Green Dot shot up 14.6% to 72.57, blasting past a 69.47 flat-base buy point after reporting earnings late Wednesday. The company provides prepaid cards, debit cards and other financial products in retail stores and online.Green Dot earned $1.40 a share, up 40% vs. a year earlier and 8 cents above consensus. Revenue ran up 24.5% to $315 million, above views for $296 million.Visa climbed 0.1% and was at the upper end of the 5% buy zone of a 125.54 entry of a flat base. Mastercard added 1.3% and was a few pennies above the buy zone from a 183.83 entry in a second-stage flat base. Square climbed 0.7% to 54.65. It's still in the 5% zone from a 52.60 double-bottom buy point cleared Tuesday.Global Payments (GPN), another payment processor, rose 1.2% to 115.97 as it works on a short base with a 119.04 entry.Payment processors sit between businesses and the banks that issue credit cards. They clear transactions and help move money between the customers paying for things and the companies selling products to them. As more commerce takes place online around the world, those companies have tried to pad their technological resources.The acquisition in January made Worldpay into a massive payments provider. The company processes billions of transactions across 146 nations and 126 currencies.Dolev, in a research note in March, called the combination a "best-in-class global e-commerce asset." During Worldpay's fourth-quarter earnings call in February, management said it continued to benefit from same-store sales gains and a "pretty strong" economy in the U.S.Worldpay Group, the company Vantiv acquired to form the new Worldpay, serves a lot of businesses in the U.K. Management cited "continued macroeconomic challenges in the U.K." as negotiations to leave the European Union drag on.YOU MIGHT BE INTERESTED IN:Lessons From PayPal Stock, And 4 Keys To Make Money In 2018Top-Rated Global Payments Near Buy Zone With Earnings DuePayment Giant Visa Breaks Out On Earnings As Peers Make Bullish Moves

The Dow Jones and S&P 500 reclaimed their 50-day moving average. Crude oil rose above $71 a barrel and energy stocks such as Chevron (CVX) kept rising after President Trump pulled out from the Iran nuclear deal. Walmart (WMT) will buy 77% of Flipkart with a $16 billion investment. Nvidia (NVDA) crushed earnings views. Several top software makers broke out on earnings. China internets had mixed results, while solar stocks shined on earnings and new regulation.XThe S&P 500, Dow Jones industrial average and Nasdaq composite rallied strongly, rising 2.4%, 2.3% and 2.7%, respectively. The S&P 500 and Dow joined the Nasdaq above their 50-day moving averages. Breakouts proliferated, including several oil, payments and software stocks.President Trump announced the U.S. would leave the nuclear deal and the global oil markets could lose 500,000 barrels per day of Iranian crude next year if all the sanctions are reinstituted. Crude, which had rallied strongly leading up to the announcement, topped $71 a barrel after the decision. Crude closed the week up 1.4% at $70.70. The Energy Information Administration now sees 2018 U.S. crude output averaging 10.72 million barrels per day, up 0.3% from a prior forecast, and sees 2019 output averaging 11.86 million barrels a day, a 3.6% upward revision. The EIA said weekly crude inventories fell by 2.2 million barrels last week, more than analysts forecast. Domestic crude output climbed to 10.7 million barrels per day. Occidental Petroleum (OXY) announced strong Q1 earnings and buyback plans. Diamondback Energy (FANG) Q1 results also beat analyst estimates. Oil majors Chevron (CVX) and Royal Dutch Shell (RDSA) cleared buy points.Green Dot (GDOT), which provides prepaid cards and other financial products, soared past a buy point on strong earnings. Payments tech company Worldpay (WP) beat Q1 estimates, but its outlook appeared to disappoint Wall Street, pushing shares away from buying territory. Visa (V), and Square (SQ) remained within buy range, moving to the high end of the range. Mastercard (MA) is slightly extending. Payments processor Global Payments (GPN) made its way through a base.Graphics-chip maker Nvidia smashed Wall Street's targets for its fiscal first quarter thanks to strong gaming and data-center chip sales. Nvidia earned $1.98 a share, up 151% year over year, on sales of $3.21 billion, up 66%. For the current quarter, its Q2, Nvidia expects sales to rise 39% to $3.1 billion, edging views of $2.97 billion. But it sees a big drop in cryptocurrency chip sales. Shares fell 2.15% Friday after rallying to a new high ahead of its earnings. Microchip Technology (MCHP) beat consensus for the March quarter and guided current-quarter views slightly higher.SolarEdge (SEDG) surged as the solar power company reported strong first-quarter earnings and gave bullish guidance. SolarEdge will enter the multibillion dollar market for uninterruptible power supply systems, by agreeing to buy Gamatronic Electronic. Solar stocks rallied across the board, including SunPower (SPWR) and Sunrun (RUN), after California became the first state to require solar panels on almost all new homes.Walmart (WMT) has beaten Amazon (AMZN) in their battle for control of Flipkart by agreeing to pay $16 billion for a 77% stake in the Indian e-commerce giant, which was founded by ex-Amazon employees. Walmart says it's a "significant opportunity" to partner with the local leader in a large, fast-growing market. But Walmart's slumping stock fell to a seven-month low. Walmart's largest-ever acquisition requires regulatory approval in India.Social network Weibo (WB) and parent Sina (SINA) topped first-quarter earnings estimates, but both stocks suffered double-digit losses. E-commerce company JD.com (JD) received price target cuts following a quarterly report that fell short of Wall Street estimates, though revenue beat. China auto website provider Autohome (ATHM) reported better-than-expected earnings and also nudged second-quarter revenue forecasts higher, sending the stock up.Online travel company Booking Holdings (BKNG), formerly Priceline, plunged as it reported quarterly results that beat views but gave an outlook that missed estimates, as the company makes ongoing changes to its marketing strategy. TripAdvisor (TRIP) soared after delivering a first-quarter report above consensus and raising 2018 guidance on stronger mobile monetization.New Relic (NEWR), Pegasystems (PEGA), Cornerstone OnDemand (CSOD) all broke out on earnings reports, with Upland Software (UPLD) and HubSpot (HUBS) flirting with a buy zone. RingCentral (RNG) moved above a buy range on results.New Relic, whose cloud software lets companies monitor business applications, servers and mobile applications, swung to a 9-cent profit, vs. views for 5 cents, with revenue up 34% to $98.4 million and billings up 43%. Pegasystems earnings fell more than expected, but the customer service software maker's revenue topped. Cornerstone OnDemand earnings grew 75% with revenue up 19% to $133 million. Upland, which makes software for project and information technology management, workflow automation, and digital engagement, reported that adjusted profit leapt 131% and revenue 52%. HubSpot profit spiked 400% while 2018 EPS guidance was strong. RingCentral said that adjusted earnings were 16 cents a share, up 77% from a year ago, with revenue rising 34% to $150 million. Its cloud communications platform offers customers voice, chat, conferencing and app integration.LGI Homes (LGIH) EPS jumped 115% as revenue popped 71% to $279 million, both much better than views. But shares reversed sharply lower as the entry-level homebuilders said costs were rising. Meanwhile, simulated-wood decking products maker Trex (TREX) and building materials firm TopBuild (BLD) broke out on strong earnings. Real estate website operator Zillow (Z) rose for the week after initially tumbling following its earnings beat.Comcast (CMCSA) has reportedly thrown its hat into the ring in a bid for 21st Century Fox (FOXA) entertainment assets with a $60 billion bid, trying to trump a Walt Disney (DIS) deal. Disney's studio revenue popped 21% in Q2, as overall revenue at the media giant rose 7% to $14.23 billion and EPS grew 12% to $1.68, topping views. "Black Panther" was a highlight. The theme parks unit grew 13%. Disney said its ESPN+ streaming service is off to a good start. Meanwhile, 21st Century Fox EPS fell 9% to 49 cents a share, missing estimates, on a 2% revenue slip to $7.42 billion, above views.Dropbox (DBX) earned an adjusted 8 cents a share, up from 2 cents a year ago, doubling estimates of 4 cents in its first quarterly report since its March IPO. Revenue rose 28% to $316 million, beating estimates of $267 million. The provider of data-storage and business-collaboration services forecast June quarter and 2018 revenue slightly above estimates.Takeda Pharmaceuticals put up a winning $62 billion bid to buy rare-disease specialist Shire (SHPG) in a deal expected to close in the first half of 2019.Ligand Pharmaceuticals (LGND) reported adjusted income of $1.55 per share on $56.2 million in sales, rising a respective 172% and 92% year over year to top views.Etsy (ETSY) reported first-quarter results that topped views and showed improving fundamentals, with the e-commerce site's growth accelerating and margin expanding as it raised 2018 guidance.Planet Fitness (PLNT) topped first-quarter estimates, but costs rose and the fitness chain didn't raise guidance. Shares fell nearly 5% Wednesday but were up 0.1% for the week.SailPoint (SAIL) reported adjusted Q1 earnings and revenue that beat expectations but in-line guidance for the June quarter disappointed, sending shares in the cybersecurity firm down. SailPoint sells identity management software that helps companies monitor security breaches.GoDaddy (GDDY) reported Q1 profit that met views as revenue and free cash flow beat, sending shares up. Analysts expect the web hosting and internet domain registering company to use growing FCF for acquisitions and to expand internationally.Trade Desk (TTD) earned 34 cents a share, up 88%, on revenue of $85.7 million, up 61%, blasting past views for 10 cents and $73.2 million. The online ad tech firm forecast Q2 revenue of $103 million vs. estimates of $95 million. Shares vaulted 43% on Friday.Video game publisher Electronic Arts (EA) reported better-than-expected results for its fiscal fourth quarter thanks to strength in key franchises such as "FIFA," "Battlefield" and "The Sims."Streaming video platform Roku (ROKU) delivered a beat-and-raise first-quarter report on gains in advertising-supported internet video channels. Roku ended the quarter with 20.8 million active accounts, up 1.5 million from the end of 2017, but shares fell.Zebra Technologies (ZBRA), a maker of asset tracking systems, trounced expectations for first-quarter sales and earnings and guided analysts up for the current quarter, sending its stock soaring.Starbucks (SBUX) will get $7.15 billion up-front from Nestle, which will sell Starbucks products around the world. Starbucks will use the cash to accelerate share buybacks and return $20 billion in cash to shareholders via buybacks and dividends.

Rising interest rates aren't bothering Joseph Eberhardy, a manager of Wells Fargo Growth Fund (SGRAX), so maybe they should not scare you either. Instead, rising rates have whetted investors' appetites for quality growth stocks vs. defensive, dividend paying stocks in general, Eberhardy says.And history has taught Eberhardy and lead manager Tom Ognar that as long as the 10-year Treasury rate stays below 5%, leading growth stocks are safe. That bodes well in general for top holdings like Paycom Software (PAYC), Netflix (NFLX), Splunk (SPLK), Amazom.com (AMZN), PayPal (PYPL) and Nvidia (NVDA) that continue to drive the $4.7 billion portfolio's returns."My gut says (the hindrance threshold for growth stocks) may be something less than 5% this time around, but we're not overly concerned with rates now around 3%," Eberhardy said.Going into Wednesday, those stocks were up this year 2% for PayPal to 60% for Netflix. Still, in the always-fluid mix of the market, the Eberhardy-Ognar team is hedging its bet on one of those leaders. (Lower in this story, we explain which one and why.)Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseMeanwhile, the overall strategy has paid off. So far this year the fund's 5.28% advance tops 88% of its large-cap growth peers tracked by Morningstar Inc. and outstrips the S&P 500's 0.9% setback. Over the past 12 months the fund is up 24.23% vs. 18.56% on average for its direct rivals and 13.17% for the broad market benchmark.Key trends trump rising rates for Eberhardy. Growth stocks that Eberhardy and Ognar like the most are those with a tailwind from key secular trends. One such trend is the migration toward software as a service (SaaS). An example is Paycom, a provider of cloud-based human capital management software.But the fund has made big trims in Paycom in recent disclosures. "Valuation was the key component for our trimming Paycom, as we thought the gap between our expectations and the market's expectations narrowed significantly," Eberhardy said.Paycom is trading at roughly 10 times its calendar 2019 enterprise value to sales ratio. ServiceNow (NOW) is a SaaS stock that the fund likes more. "We like NOW better," Eberhardy said. With its slightly lower valuation of calendar 2019 nine times EV to sales ratio, "we see a little more opportunity for margin expansion with NOW as they accelerate new investments into areas like HR," he said.The rise of cloud computing and storage is another trend the fund plays. Splunk is a hybrid play in cloud computing and SaaS, Eberhardy says. This company's software helps customers crunch big data, "whether it's real-time monitoring for cybersecruity or helping locomotive operators optimize their driving to cut fuel costs," he said.Amazon is a long-time top holding and the poster child for a company capitalizing on the growth of online retail. "They are the dominant provider in that space, and we see that continuing going forward," Eberhardy said. "They also fit the cloud computing trend through their web services side. AWS (Amazon Web Services) is roughly 10% of their revenues but 90% of their total operating income."PayPal is a leader in the digital payments trend. "The shift from paper to digital payments benefits them, Global Payments (GPN) and Square (SQ), Eberhardy said, citing two additional holdings. "We still feel that there's a big opportunity for all of them. PayPal stands to be one of the biggest beneficiaries."A fifth trend the fund aims to exploit is the rise of the Internet of Things. Chipmaker Nvidia is one way to play that trend. "Whether it's on the gaming side or in autonomous vehicles, Nvidia is the clear leader," Eberhardy said. "Nvidia has been the dominant provider of chips in those two spaces. Their lead, their competitive moat, is relatively stable."Of course no stock or sector rises forever, Eberhardy cautions. "There's still lots of opportunities in those five areas," he said, referring to the five trends. "But some areas in particular, like SaaS in the last few months, have been trading toward the high end of their historical valuation ranges. That's something to watch. The other four are more fairly valued. To a lesser extent, cloud computing is closer to its higher end than its lower end."YOU MAY ALSO LIKE:Want Tax-Free Retirement Income? Fidelity Investments' plan is that shareholders of Growth Discovery Fund (FDSVX) will find their usual satisfaction in the first five or so months of the year. In that span, Asher Anolic will temporarily take the helm from marquee manager Jason Weiner, who will spend that period away from the fund on a leave of absence, traveling with his family and pursuing educational opportunities.X Anolic will be the acting manager not only of the $1.7 billion Growth Discovery but also of its advisor-sold twin, $3.1 billion Advisor Equity Growth (FAEGX).For Anolic, the challenge is weighty. Weiner, who has steered the funds since February 2007 and early November of 2006 respectively, has led them to rarefied success.The funds outperformed the broad market in the form of the S&P 500 in the latest calendar year, 2017, as well as the three and five years ended Dec. 31. If the funds keep up that pace and add outperformance over the past 10 years, they will earn inclusion as IBD Best Mutual Funds Awards winners. Only 4% of U.S. diversified stock mutual funds with at least $100 million in assets pulled off that feat by the end of 2016.Weiner — with Anolic as co-manager since July 1 — achieved that multiperiod outperformance with portfolios featuring leading stocks like Five Below (FIVE), Red Hat (RHT) and Alibaba Group (BABA), as well as household names like Facebook (FB)  and Amazon.com (AMZN), two of the FANG stocks.Shortly before 48-year-old Weiner began his sabbatical, he and 39-year-old Anolic talked with IBD from their Boston offices about their managerial juggling act and how their investment styles overlap and how they differ.IBD: Jason, has your management style changed since Asher joined you as co-manager?Weiner: Absolutely, yes. Any time you take on a partner, you talk about what you think, what your partner thinks. Ash came with experience in health care and staples, and with a much sharper quantitative investment focus. No two people have the same skill set. So one plus one equals more than two.IBD: Asher, have you changed?Anolic: With my background in staples and health care and financials, I never had a chance to encounter some of the big open-ended growth stories that Jason has done an excellent job figuring out. Those companies can have huge addressable markets, which become multiples of what people think they are today.In the past, I would have shied away from those because I was afraid of getting caught in something that I wasn't able to visualize where it could go. Jason's been great helping me out there.IBD: Since before the 2016 elections, the fund has swung toward cyclical stocks, then growth stocks, then back to cyclicals. How has that worked for the fund?Weiner: In 2016 growth didn't perform well and we didn't get paid for owning them. We got it all back in 2017 for the first three-quarters of the year. In the last quarter those leadership names took a breather. But I think it's healthy because we don't want a bubble.We stuck with growth. Now our job is to look forward into 2018 and figure out how to extend the process. No matter what the short-term gyrations are, how do we stick with names that are growing earnings and adding value?IBD: What's been the biggest change in the market during your career, Jason?Weiner: When I started at Fidelity in 1991, I was a junior analyst picking small-cap names. There was an inherent advantage because small companies were where you found little trees that grew into big trees.Today, it's completely the opposite. The only companies growing fast are the biggest companies in the world, companies with market caps of $500 billion. That's really driven by internet economics. This is very different, very unique.IBD: And you still look for the best growth opportunities, with an overlay of valuation sensitivity?Weiner: That hasn't changed. We look for undervalued growth stories and stocks with the potential for price-to-earnings (P/E) expansion, while avoiding names that have unreasonably high valuations or deteriorating business fundamentals.IBD: Asher, what changes will you make while Jason is out?Anolic: Aside from the fact that I don't love the decor (which drew laughter from both Anolic and Weiner), I expect changes in less than a quarter of the holdings. Jason has constructed the portfolio with a two-year horizon. We've tested lots of what-if scenarios. Nothing should surprise us. If something does crop up out of left field, I will adjust. But the fundamental approach will not change.IBD: Does Facebook still meet your valuation check box?Weiner: It's valuation is a lot higher than a year ago. It occurred because they grew fast. Earnings went up. They're touching 1 billion people a day with News Feed, their main product. You can sell a lot of advertising when you touch over 1 billion people a day.I still think they will improve their ad targeting. So fundamentals are intact. Can I find better value elsewhere (in another stock)? That search goes on every day. After the big move in these (internet) names in the last year, that conversation is a little more intense.IBD: With Amazon, you're comfortable that their spending will pay off within a reasonable period?Weiner: If you say retail as we knew it is dead and the retail of tomorrow is being invented as we speak, which companies are at the forefront? It is Alibaba and Amazon.We like to take a company's profit-and-loss statement and break down the business units. For Amazon, it's domestic retail and international retail and Amazon Web Services. How is each performing? What are their opportunities? With the investments they make, what will future earnings be like?IBD: Asher, what would you add?Anolic: AWS is cost intensive, more than the rest of Amazon. But it has taken a ton of market share, and has good margins and good cash flow. It's at the forefront of a major technological shift.IBD: Any more thoughts about Alibaba?Weiner: I look at Amazon and Alibaba as a pair. You want to distill the thoughts of Alibaba's Jack Ma (founder and executive chairman) and Amazon's Jeffrey Bezos (founder, chairman and CEO)? Looking at them together is helpful to understanding what those visionaries are doing. Just one part of that is inventing a new world of retail.IBD'S TAKE: For the latest news and analysis of Chinese stocks, visit IBD's special section about Chinese stocks to buy and watch.IBD: Does Five Below defy the problems of many brick-and-mortar retailers by discounting and by focusing on a teen audience?Weiner: It's too small to worry about, but I will tell you this: It's like Dollar Tree (DLTR) plus a treasure-hunt thing. Mom can bring her kids, who go to the $5 basketballs while mom goes to the $5 makeup aisle. I remember the CEO saying once, "This is the only store where you can bring your kids and not have any fears."IBD: Red Hat is the top provider of open-source Linux software for corporate data centers. Is that like being the top buggy-whip maker?Anolic: With the move to the cloud, people are worried about Red Hat's growth prospects. If you have a Linux operating system for several servers, but then you move a lot of that data to AWS or Google Cloud or Microsoft (Azure), you don't need all of those servers or that operating system.But Red Hat's core Linux business is still fantastic. Much in the cloud runs on Linux. And Red Hat is reinventing its business. They have a new product that can write programs on top of the Red Hat system and port them to different clouds. It gives CIOs the flexibility of not getting locked in to one cloud vendor. This gives some visibility to how Red Hat looks in a cloud environment. We're going to keep monitoring it. It's a fascinating solution.IBD: What business hasn't been totally disrupted, but could be eventually?Weiner: Digital payments. Payments in general have entrenched players like Visa (V) and Mastercard (MA) and card-issuing banks like Citi (C) and JPMorgan (JPM) and merchant acquirers like First Data (FDC) and Global Payments (GPN). That system has been built over decades.But PayPal has given us a taste of disruption. We've all used PayPal at checkout. Can they take that beachhead and expand into the payment space? They've already got Venmo in people-to-people payments. And they own Braintree, which (provides mobile and web payments acceptance and processing for) merchants. (The payments space) feels ripe for disruption.IBD: Why do you like Copart (CPRT)?Weiner: It's a duopoly (with KAR Auction Services (KAR)), a great business. Hurricane Irma rolls through (the Caribbean and) Florida, Harvey hits Houston, and 100,000 cars get wrecked. They get disposed of through auto auctions. Copart is family run, has super profitability and super acquisitions. When cars get totaled, sometimes the scrap value is higher than a resale value.IBD: Asher, you're continuing to run $784 million Select Pharmaceuticals (FPHAX). What's the biggest change in joining Jason at the helm of Growth Discovery?Anolic: Jason has been helpful in teaching and generous with his time. So I'm totally up to speed on what is needed. And we worked together before I was named co-manager, so I was familiar with how he runs money.The biggest change is moving from one sector to the whole market. Six months of partnering doesn't teach you everything that someone running for 20-plus years has learned. But the skill set I've built allows me to understand day-to-day market moves and how to learn as I go.IBD: Jason, was Asher's apprenticeship long enough?Weiner: Asher is an experienced investor. And the way the fund (Growth Discovery) is built, 70% of its assets are in the top 40 names, so Asher only has to learn about 40 names to understand nearly three-quarters of the portfolio. Also, Asher already knew some names from his work on other mutual funds. And we have a huge amount of research support.IBD: Jason, will you be able to hit the ground running when you return in May or so?Weiner: I think I'll be raring to go. I'll have had a nice break, but it will be nice to get back to business.YOU MAY ALSO LIKE:2018 Stock Market Forecast: Smaller Price Gains, With A Foreign TiltHot Fidelity Fund Owns Stocks Like Tencent That Jumped Friday

The S&P 500 index and other major averages edged lower through Thursday as tax reform concerns weighted on the market. Snapchat parent Snap (SNAP) crashed on weak revenue and user growth. As for M&A, Broadcom (AVGO) made a $130 billion bid for fellow Apple (AAPL) supplier Qualcomm (QCOM), while reports surfaced that Walt Disney had held talks to buy much of 21st Century Fox (FOXA).The S&P 500, Nasdaq and Dow industrials gave up weekly gains on fears that tax cuts would be delayed, closing slightly lower but still near record highs. Earnings remained heavy, with Nvidia (NVDA) leading chip earnings. Roku (ROKU) streamed higher on its strong, first-ever earnings report while fellow recent IPOs Snap and The Trade Desk (TTD) crashed. Bank stocks were notable losers for the week. Crude oil futures hit a 2-year high amid Saudi turmoil, but U.S. production hit record highs.Broadcom (AVGO) launched an unsolicited bid to buy wireless-chip maker Qualcomm (QCOM) in a deal worth $130 billion, which would make it the largest technology acquisition ever. Qualcomm is likely to reject the $70-a-share offer on the basis that it's too low. A deal also would have big antitrust hurdles. Qualcomm rose 4.5% to 64.57 after spiking nearly 13% on Nov. 3 as deal reports first hit. Broadcom retreated 3.2% but stayed in a buy range.Chipmakers Nvidia (NVDA), Microchip Technology (MCHP) and ON Semiconductor (ON) posted beat-and-raise quarterly reports. Skyworks Solutions (SWKS) beat Wall Street's targets for the September quarter, but gave in-line guidance. Among chip-gear makers, Brooks Automation (BRKS) beat fiscal fourth-quarter forecast and guided current-quarter forecasts higher, but shares still tumbled Thursday and Friday following the results.Roku (ROKU) rocketed 55% Thursday after the streaming video firm reported much better-than-expected results for the third quarter, its first as a publicly traded company. Roku then rose to a record high Friday. Roku ended the third quarter with 16.7 million active users on its content distribution platform, up 48% year over year. Average revenue per user grew 37% year over year to $12.68. Roku makes hardware and software for accessing internet video services like Netflix (NFLX), Hulu and Amazon (AMZN) Prime Video.Analysts tore into Snapchat-owner Snap (SNAP) after a third-quarter earnings report that missed estimates on many metrics, including revenue and user growth. Snap CEO Evan Spiegel acknowledged complaints that Snapchat is "hard to use" and said that the app will be redesigned. Shares crashed 16%, even with Tencent Holdings (TCEHY) buying a 12% stake in the social media firm.RELATED:Snap Slammed On Quarterly Results As Tencent Acquires A StakeThree China internet companies, Sina (SINA), Weibo (WB) and Autohome (ATHM), all reported quarterly results that beat expectations. Sina owns a controlling stake in Weibo. Chinese video game publisher NetEase (NTES) said it will push deeper into e-commerce, with plans to spend $11 billion on products from the U.S., Europe and Japan to sell to local consumers.Search-engine company Sogou (SOGO) raised $585 million in an initial public offering, selling 45 million shares at 13, the high end of its estimated range. Shares rose to 13.51 in Thursday's debut and closed Friday at 13.86. China-based Sohu (SOHU), an internet service company that includes gaming, holds the largest stake in Sogou, which is also backed by Tencent (TCEHY). Tencent leads China's messaging services field and aims to deepen its relationship with Sogou, posing a threat to China search-engine leader Baidu (BIDU).Nordstrom (JWN) roundly topped profit and revenue forecasts. But same-store sales disappointed and the upscale department store trimmed the high end of profit outlook. Meanwhile, Macy's (M) missed revenue estimates and comps sank 4%, but beaten-down shares soared on better-than-expected earnings. Kohl's (KSS) EPS missed views but the retailer lifted the bottom end of EPS targets. J.C. Penney (JCP) reported better-than-expected Q3 results after recently slashing full-year guidance.Walt Disney (DIS) disclosed a surprise drop in Q4 profit and revenue amid reports of more upcoming ESPN layoffs, but CEO Bob Iger announced that there would be a brand-new "Star Wars" trilogy, gave its ESPN streaming platform a name and launch date, and said its Disney-only over-the-top service would be priced "substantially below" Netflix (NFLX), reversing shares higher late Thursday. Meanwhile, reports surfaced that 21st Century Fox (FOXA) had held talks to sell the bulk of itself to Disney. Iger refused to address "press speculation" on the call. Disney rose solidly more than 6%. 21st Century Fox, which reported solid results, shot up 15.5%.On Monday, oil prices rose to their highest levels since mid-2015 on political unrest in the Middle East. Crude closed the week with a 2.3% gain to $56.74 a barrel. Saudi Arabia arrested several members of the royal family over the prior week and said that a missile attack from Yemen and supported by Iran could be considered an "act of war." U.S. crude production rose to 9.62 million barrels per day, the highest since Energy Information Administration began tracking weekly data in 1983. Domestic crude supplies unexpectedly rose. Continental Resources (CLR), Diamondback Energy (FANG), Matador Resources (MTDR), and Carrizo Oil & Gas (CRZO) topped quarterly forecasts, while Parsley Energy (PE) turned in mixed results as shale producers continued to stress capital spending discipline in their Q3 reports.RELATED:U.S. Crude Production Hits Record High, Stockpiles Unexpectedly RiseVideo game publisher Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO) reported better-than-expected September-quarter results and guided higher for the holiday sales quarter after Activision Blizzard (ATVI) and Electronic Arts (EA) recently gave disappointing guidance. Take-Two is benefiting from continued demand for its "Grand Theft Auto" franchise and strong sales of basketball game "NBA 2K18." Meanwhile, Activision said "Call of Duty: WWII" surpassed $500 million in global sales in its first three days of availability.Sage Therapeutics (SAGE) rose to a record high on upbeat data for a postpartum depression drug while Teva Pharmaceutical (TEVA) popped on news a British billionaire could buy a stake. Supernus Pharma (SUPN) topped expectations late Monday and boosted its 2017 product sales guidance. Ionis Pharmaceuticals (IONS) dove on its third-quarter miss and Mallinckrodt (MNK) offered a mixed report Tuesday, causing it to lose a third of its value. Nektar Therapeutics (NKTR), Acadia Pharmaceuticals (ACAD) and Tesaro (TSRO) all beat top- and bottom-line views, but Tesaro plunged after sales of ovarian cancer drug Zejula lagged. Meanwhile, AstraZeneca (AZN) had strong ovarian cancer drug and overall revenue, but adjusted profit was soft. Regeneron Pharmaceuticals (REGN) on Wednesday topped revenue and earnings views and confirmed guidance for 10% yearly Eylea growth.Priceline Group (PCLN) topped third-quarter estimates but the online travel agency's weak earnings outlook sent shares plunging 13.5% on Tuesday. Priceline's accommodation business booked 178 million room nights, up 19%. TripAdvisor (TRIP) also fell after reporting missing Q3 revenue estimates, as its hotel business slowed.Square (SQ) reported Q3 adjusted EPS of 7 cents, two cents above consensus. The digital payment processor said net revenue rose 33% to $585 million, topping estimates. The maker of credit card readers that plug into mobile phones and tablets raised its full year revenue and adjusted EBITDA outlooks by 4% and 8%, respectively, at the midpoint of guidance.The digital ad placement company's adjusted third-quarter earnings rose 46% to 35 cents a share, with revenue climbing nearly 50% to $79.4 million, topping consensus estimates. But The Trade Desk (TTD) forecast Q4 revenue of $101 million vs. estimates of $102 million, and also gave weak EBITDA guidance. The Trade Desk crashed 14% on Friday after already tumbling 8.3% through Thursday.Homebuilder D.R. Horton (DHI) met earnings estimates and topped revenue forecasts. Shares rose to record highs.Alarm.com (ALRM) plunged after the home security and automation software firm forecast full-year earnings at 87-88 cents per share vs. estimates of 97 cents.Match Group (MTCH) stock jumped after the dating site operator forecast December-quarter revenue above expectations, owing to mobile app Tinder Gold, despite a miss on Q3 earnings.Planet Fitness (PLNT) put up Q3 results and a full-year forecast above consensus. However, Wedbush said that it was still cautious, given concerns about "decelerating growth as the store base matures."Monster Beverage (MNST) beat third-quarter sales estimates, but earnings missed. Shares fell below a buy point intraday Thursday below a buy point but closed 6% higher for the week.General Electric (GE) may sell or spin off its aircraft leasing business as new CEO John Flannery looks to slash more than $20 billion in assets and costs at the troubled industrial giant in 1-2 years. GE's locomotive and health care IT units were also recently said to face the knife.Industrial laser maker Coherent (COHR) saw its shares blast past a buy point after delivering better-than-expected September-quarter sales and earnings and guiding higher for the current quarter. Coherent is a play on OLED display production growth.Global Payments (GPN) expects full-year adjusted net revenue of $3.505 billion to $3.53 billion, up about 23%. But most of that gain is due to the payment processor's recent acquisition of Active Network, analysts said.

U.S. stock indexes stayed near the break-even line midday Wednesday, but the market received some bullish news from the CEO of BlackRock (BLK), the world's largest asset manager.The Nasdaq rose 0.1%, while the Dow Jones industrial average and  S&P 500 were essentially flat.XThe small-cap Russell 2000 added 0.1%. Volume in the stock market today was lower across the board compared to the same time Tuesday.BlackRock reported Q3 results, topping the consensus view on earnings and revenue. The broader economic outlook held potentially bigger news. CEO Larry Fink told CNBC that there is still a lot of money "sitting on the sideline." Fink said that "even in places like Japan, there's $5 trillion in cash earning negative return. In Germany 72% of savings are in bank accounts."He added, "We're seeing some of that unlocked, we're seeing people put some of that money to work."The money on the sideline suggests that there could be more gains ahead for the stock market in the long term. The classic definition of a market top involves virtually no money on the sidelines.But that doesn't mean there won't be pullbacks along the way. Investors Intelligence's percentage of bullish advisors is at 60.4%, a level associated with pullbacks. Late July was the last time the level was that high, and a 4.4% pullback in the Nasdaq followed.BlackRock's stock opened almost 2% higher Wednesday but then retreated to a 0.8% gain. The stock hit a new high, something many financial and bank stocks have been doing lately. Through Tuesday's session, banks and financial stocks have supplied the most daily new highs for 15 sessions in a row.Several banks will be reporting quarterly results this week. Citigroup (C) and JPMorgan Chase (JPM) will report before the open Thursday. Bank of America (BAC) and Wells Fargo (WFC) will report before Friday's open.Breakouts were scarce midday Wednesday, but a few stocks showed positive action.Alphabet (GOOGL) rose 9.14 to 996.94 in average turnover. The stock is approaching a buy point at 1,006.29. Alphabet is expected to grow earnings 10% this year and 31% in 2018.Payment processor Global Payments (GPN) advanced 0.59 to 99.11. The stock is still in the buy zone from a 98.09 buy point. The Street expects Global to grow earnings 24% this year and 18% next year.Home furnishings provider RH (RH), formerly known as Restoration Hardware, popped 3.26 to 77.46 in volume was running at its 50-day average. The Street's consensus estimate calls for an earnings gain of 106% in fiscal 2018 ending in January and a 46% increase in fiscal 2019.Among IBD's 197 industry groups, steel producers and dairy held the biggest daily gains. Retail groups were among the day's biggest losers.RELATED:Which Sectors Are Attracting Fund Money?This Item Won't Help Time The Market, But It's Useful

JPMorgan Mid Cap Growth Fund (HLGEX) has heated up this year thanks to leading-stock holdings like electronic parts maker Amphenol (APH), electronic payments processor Global Payments (GPN) and hotels-resorts-timeshares operator Hilton Worldwide (HLT). Their gains year to date range from 22% for Amphenol to 36% for Global.XAnd to help keep the good times rolling, the $3.2 billion fund is betting on top new buys as of its latest disclosure such as IPG Photonics (IPGP), a maker of fiber-optic lasers for industrial and medical applications; Linux operating system distributor Red Hat (RHT); and semiconductor test-equipment maker Teradyne (TER).Year-to-date gains by those newcomers ranged from 45% by Teradyne to 87% for IPG. On Tuesday, Red Hat gapped up 4% the day after reporting a 40% jump in adjusted fiscal second-quarter earnings per share, which topped analysts' expectations. It also raised its guidance for revenue and profit for the full year.The company's software runs computer servers in corporate data centers. Red Hat's cloud-computing revenue is mainly from customers using software-as-a-service.IBD'S TAKE: Red Hat is the No. 1 ranked stock in IBD's Computer Software-Desktop industry group. See how its fundamental and technical strengths stack up against rivals' in IBD's easy-to-use Stock Checkup tool. That's one of several premium IBD features you can take for a test drive for free through Oct. 8. Other popular premium offerings include exclusive stock lists and The Big Picture, a daily update of what's driving the market.For the fund, all of that good news translated into a 21.64% gain this year going into Thursday. That outperformed 87% of the fund's midcap growth peers tracked by Morningstar Direct and easily topped the S&P 500's 13.66% return.The fund produced a three-year average annual gain of 9.13% vs. the big-cap bogey's 10.43% pace and the fund peer group's 8.59%.One reason the three-year tempo lags year-to-date gain is the three-year average includes the fund's paltry 2016 gain of 0.19%, which lagged 91% of its direct rivals.That makes this year, so far, the poster child for the fund's approach, which aims for capital growth through midcap- stocks with above-average growth. As the fund's latest fact sheet puts it, the fund's managers seek companies that are industry leaders, with business models that hold up in a variety of markets and whose executives know how to steer their charges to outsized growth.Timothy Parton just notched his 13th anniversary at the helm of the fund. Felise Agranoff has been a manager for about a year and nine months.Take a closer look at some of the fund's leading stocks. Portfolio newcomer Teradyne has IBD's next-to-highest-possible Composite Rating of 98. Scored on a scale of 1 to 99, stocks poised to move higher often have a Comp Rating of 95 or higher.The maker of automated test equipment for the chip industry also has an A SMR Rating, which means it is in the top 20% of stocks in terms of sales growth, profit margins and return-on-equity ratios, based on IBD's proprietary formula.The chip-testing systems firm serves the automobile, computing and game markets.In addition, Teradyne is in IBD's 85-85 index. The index tracks stocks whose EPS and Relative Strength Ratings are 85 or greater, and whose prices are above $15, are within 15% of their 52-week high and whose average daily trading volume is 10,000 shares or more.In July, the company's second-quarter report showed earnings per share up 64%. The 31% jump in revenue was the biggest jump in at least 19 quarters. Teradyne said results in the first half of the year were driven by strength in mobility, automotive, analog, microcontroller and memory end markets.Bright Horizons (BFAM) is another top new buy. Earnings per share growth has accelerated, having climbed 14%, 19%, 20% and 21% the past four quarters. The firm provides child care, early education and other services.It sports a 95 Comp Rating and an A SMR Rating.The rise in Q2 revenue and EPS growth was driven by both new full-service child-care centers and improved results from existing ones, the company said. Price increases averaged 3% to 4%. In addition, sales of backup dependent care and educational advisory services expanded.Fortive (FTV), a newcomer to the portfolio, makes equipment for testing and measurement, many for field instruments. EPS rose 13% and 11% the past two quarters, up from 1% the prior stanza.A spinoff from Danaher (DHR), Fortive was held by 1,388 mutual funds as of June 30. That was up from 1,305 funds as of Sept. 30, 2016. Funds' collective stakes rose to 148.3 million shares, up from 135.1 million shares.RELATED:Looking For Winning Stocks? IBD 50 growth stocks have greatly outpaced the S&P 500 index, Nasdaq composite and other major averages in 2017. While many IBD 50 stocks are extended, here are five members that are near buy points in bullish bases: Facebook (FB), Apple (AAPL) chipmaker Skyworks Solutions (SWKS), laser technology firm Coherent (COHR), Stamps.com (STMP) and Global Payments (GPN).XSkyworks, Coherent and Global Payments have risen above entry points, at least intraday, in recent sessions. Facebook has traded tightly for several weeks.IBD 50 stocks were up an average of 69.5% through Sept. 14, vs. 11.5% for the S&P 500 index.The major averages are trading at all-time highs even as the Fed is expected to begin whittling down its massive $4.5 trillion balance sheet today. That's been well-telegraphed by policymakers. But will they stick to their relatively hawkish forecasts for future interest rate hikes with inflation low and market expectations even lower?Facebook rose 1.5% to 172.52 in Tuesday's stock market trading. The social networking giant is in a flat base going back to July 27, with a 175.59 buy point. Its Facebook's first real consolidation since late January.Facebook could soon win approval to enter China, according to an analyst report Tuesday. Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg has made several trips to China, taking lessons in Mandarin Chinese as part of a long-term effort to win over authorities. Facebook has more than 2 billion users but has largely been shut out of China, the world's largest internet market.Skyworks rose 0.4% on Tuesday to 107.93, just below a 108.65 cup-with-handle base. Skyworks broke out on Sept. 15, but fell back below that entry on Monday as Apple slumped amid concerns that iPhone 8 preorders are lackluster. Apple itself remains comfortably in buy range, however, up 6 cents to 158.73. A few other iPhone-related chip plays are starting to move out as well, including Texas Instruments (TXN) and Applied Materials (AMAT).Coherent shot up as high as 281 intraday Tuesday, briefly topping a 278.49 cup-base buy point. But the stock pulled back to close at 265.87, up 1.85%.Coherent makes laser systems and components for a variety of uses, including fiber optics and OLED screens. OLED plays are gaining interest as Apple will use the next-generation display tech for its upcoming iPhone X.Coherent has reported huge and accelerating profit, but shares plunged Aug. 2 as earnings fell short of lofty views.Stamps.com rose 1.6% to 208.20 on Tuesday, working its way through a consolidation with a 220.35 entry. Stamps.com broke out of a cup pattern in late May, then skyrocketed 36% on Aug. 3 following strong earnings.Global Payments fell 0.9% to 96.06 on Tuesday, its fourth decline in five sessions. On Sept. 12, shares rose as high as 98.14, just inching past a 98.09 buy point, but closing just below that level.Payment stocks have been market leaders in the past few months, with newcomers PayPal (PYPL) and Square (SQ) joining Visa (V) and Mastercard (MA) among those breaking out to record highs.RELATED:The Big Picture: Stocks Bide Time Ahead Of Fed; IBD 50 LeadsThis Is How Much IBD 50 Stocks Are Beating The MarketIBD 50 List Of Top-Rated Growth StocksApple Leads 7 Top Stocks Holding In Buy RangeFacebook's Long-Awaited Entry Into China Market May Be NearStocks To Buy And Watch: Top IPOs, Big And Small Caps, Growth Stocks

After a big run — over 50% — from an April 25 breakout, Square (SQ) investors may have expected a more significant correction, but the stock appears to have slowed its recent slide as it builds the right side of a potential base. The stock market's ascent has slowed since June. But Wells Fargo Growth Fund's Tom Ognar sees a buying opportunity for the kinds of growth stocks his fund holds, which include PayPal (PYPL), Alibaba (BABA), Nvidia (NVDA) and Netflix (NFLX).X"The market has been a little more defensive, and it seems some higher multiple stocks have corrected a little — but nothing too discouraging," said Ognar, who is lead manager of $4.4 billion Growth Fund (SGRAX). "To us, it opens opportunities. It has made many secular growth stocks more attractively valued."Those are the kinds of stocks that Ognar and co-managers Bruce Olson and Joseph Eberhardy aim for and that have fueled the fund's long-term outperformance. "The Growth Fund has always had a bias (in favor of) investing in longer-term secular growth companies that exhibit robust and sustainable growth," Ognar said. Many are built for vigorous growth in a variety of economic conditions.That focus has driven the fund in the long term. Ognar has been a manager of this portfolio since May 2002. Going into Thursday, over the past 15 years the fund's 11.53% average annual gain outpaced 93% of its peer group tracked by Morningstar Inc. and the big-cap bogey's 9.01% average yearly gain.This year the fund has tacked on an additional 22.16%, topping 80% of its direct rivals, despite a rocky past three months during which the fund beat only 43% of its peers.Olson has been a co-manager since the start of 2005. Eberhardy has been a manager since late April 2008.The recent downturn is certainly not the only time that the managers have added to names they like. They added to positions in recent quarters in several favorites, including PayPal, Alibaba, Nvidia and Netflix.PayPal benefits from the shift to electronic payments for transactions. That trend is driven by the need to make electronic payments for online transactions. It's also driven by global governments' desire to track transactions so they can assess taxes. The stock is a member of the IBD 50 list of stocks that have strong relative price strength and fundamentals.PayPal isn't the only holding that benefits from that trend. "Square (SQ), Visa (V), Mastercard (MA), Global Payments (GPN) all benefit from the transition away from cash," Ognar said. "The other big push for that (group) is the movement from offline, brick-and-mortar retailers to online retailers."In addition, a change in PayPal's business strategy has cut a source of risk. "PayPal has evolved its business model," Ognar said. "It no longer fights with peers. It has made them more partners. It has signed partnerships with Visa and Mastercard, where it no longer creates barriers (for consumers) using Visa and Mastercard. Now it makes it easier for consumers to make payments through Visa and Mastercard using the PayPal platform."Alibaba, China's leading online retail marketplace, benefits from the growth of online retail, the same trend that helps Amazon, Ognar notes, and it is diversifying geographically. "We've felt there was an opportunity there since the (Alibaba) IPO," Ognar said.Both stocks are on Leaderboard — IBD's premium service that spotlights play-by-play of top stocks.A third trend that the fund plays is "the digitization of the economy and consumer," Ognar said. He added, "It's a compelling growth opportunity for semiconductor firms," Ognar said. Chipmaker Nvidia, which is another member of the IBD 50, benefits from the shift toward more use of graphics processing units, away from regular CPU computer chips, because of their faster processing speeds in applications such as gaming, driverless and driver-assisted cars, and cryptocurrencies, as well as machine learning and artificial intelligence.EPS grew at a triple-digit pace in four of the past five quarters.IBD'S TAKE: Nvidia is the No. 1 stock in IBD's Electronics-Semiconductor Fabless industry group. It earned that spot in part by posting a 56% jump in sales last quarter and a 27.6% annual pretax margin. You can compare its other technical and fundamental strengths with its rivals' at IBD's easy-to-use Stock Checkup tool.Portfolio newcomer Netflix is too small of a holding to be the poster child for any broad investment theme for the fund, Ognar says. Still, the stock popped 3.5% on Wednesday. IBD readers saw that the video-streaming service bounced off its 50-day moving average, rising toward a buy point.Among other holdings, Microchip Technology (MCHP) is another chipmaker that benefits from digitization of the economy and consumer. "Electronics and digitization are influencing more of what we do and the products we use to do those things," Ognar said.Microchip Tech's products include signal microcontrollers. "They're like little full-blown computers within thermostats in your home, the entertainment system of your car, or camera, or brake system of your car," he said.While the fund has trimmed its Microchip stake, the stock is still the fund's largest chipmaker. Shares are up 34% so far this year.The fund has trimmed stocks that have been big share-price gainers this year, including software titan Microsoft (MSFT) and video game publisher Activision Blizzard (ATVI), to reduce their weightings. "It's more of a risk-management move as they've grown in position size, not because of a degradation in growth opportunities," Ognar said. RELATED:What's The Stock Market Doing Now?Are You A Newcomer To Stock Investing Who Wants A Few Pointers? Talk about hot! Brian Demain is lead manager of $14.2 billion Janus Henderson Enterprise (JANEX), which is an IBD 2017 Best Mutual Fund Awards winner. So is the fund's twin, $1 billion Aspen Enterprise (JAAGX), of which he also is skipper.XThe portfolios won Best Funds honors by outperforming the S&P 500 in four time periods ended Dec. 31 — the trailing one, three, five and 10 years.And they did so in not just one category but in three — diversified equity mutual funds, growth mutual funds and midcap mutual funds.That put them into a small group of gems. A mere 44 U.S. diversified stock mutual funds, out of 1,104 with assets of at least $100 million, prevailed as winners across those four time spans.Demain and Cody Wheaton run the funds with little turnover, just 20% now, according to Morningstar Inc. Among both portfolios' holdings are Crown Castle (CCI), Microchip Technology (MCHP), Global Payments (GPN), Sensata Technologies (ST) and TD Ameritrade (AMTD). All are either forming basing patterns or in buy ranges.Enterprise is open to investors who already own shares. It's also open to old or new shareholders in 401(k) plans that already offer the fund, as well as to old or new investor clients of a wirehouse brokerage that offers the identical strategy through a separately managed account. Twin sister Aspen Enterprise can be bought by old or new investors through some insurance companies.A midcap fund at Janus Henderson that is still open to new investors is $4 billion Mid Cap Value (JMIVX).Demain, who is 40 years old, talked about his investment approach and several key stock holdings in a recent interview with IBD:IBD: Brian, summarize your investment approach.Demain: First, we look for what we call sustainable growth. We want companies that are growth companies today and will be three, five, seven years from now. They may not be the fastest growers, but they can grow for the long term.Second, we're looking for companies with sustainably high returns on invested capital. It's great if a company can grow. But if it's not earning high returns on invested capital, it's not increasing shareholder value. So we try to understand a company's competitive advantage, because that's what will drive its long-term return on invested capital.Third, we care about the quality of a company's management team. We like management teams that focus on the right areas, and that are good leaders.If we find companies that meet those three criteria and we can buy them at attractive valuations and hold them for the long term, we can outperform our peers.IBD: The fund's performance is consistent, as shown by its being an IBD Best Mutual Funds Awards winner. Is the key its outperformance during up markets or during down markets?Demain: We've generally been able to keep up in up markets and outperform in down markets. We try to have a predicted beta (a measurement of volatility relative to the market or benchmark) against our Russell MidCap Growth Index benchmark of between 0.85 and 1, so we have less absolute risk than the benchmark. But it's higher than 0.85, because we don't want to only outperform in a down market. That's where we want to shine, but we do OK in up markets as well.IBD: Why do you like midcaps?Demain: They're not as mature as large caps, so they have real growth opportunities ahead of them. But their business models are more established than small caps'.Many have withstood competitive challenges, which small caps may not have. But they tend to be less volatile than small caps.IBD: You've got about 70% of your assets in the technology, industrials and health care sectors. Why do you expect to find so many opportunities in those spaces?Demain: With tech and health care, it is the power of innovation. In tech, we've been overweight in hardware and semiconductors. The mobile internet is driving semiconductor growth. And we're seeing a lot of innovation in software pushing itself into our lives.In health, we own biotechs, pharmaceuticals, life-science tools and diagnostic companies. Aging baby boomers and an emerging middle class globally are driving innovations in drug development and diagnostics.IBD: You've noted that corporate tax cuts, infrastructure spending and deregulation may not occur as fast as many investors have hoped. How have you hedged your bets on those areas?Demain: Take tax cuts. Sensata is a Netherlands domiciled company (which makes sensors for aircraft, cars and other products) but it does business in the U.S. It pays a low tax rate because of where it is domiciled, so it will not benefit from lower U.S. rates.We also own TD Ameritrade (which is a brokerage). It pays a full tax rate, so if there's reform it will benefit. But policy changes can cut both ways. Ameritrade also benefits from rising interest rates. It sweeps clients' cash balances into TD Bank and earns more money on that spread as rates rise. And we own Crown Castle (a REIT that owns wireless cell towers). It has high levels of borrowing, so it will be hurt by high interest rates.IBD: Lam Research (LRCX) must be one of your semiconductor plays. Describe it, please.Demain: They are a semiconductor capital equipment manufacturer. In the last few years, we've gone from everything being etched on one plane of each microchip to effectively stacked layers on chips. So a lot of growth has gone to etching deposition players like Lam.In addition, demand in the memory market is robust. That's driven by uptake in solid-state drives. We're going from the old disk drives to solid-state flash-driven drives. That demands lots of chips, which is good for Lam.And we like their valuation. The stock trades at 13.5 times forward earnings. If you back out their cash, it is close to 12 times. The market's multiple is north of 18 times. And several high quality semiconductor companies are trading at 20 times.IBD: Celgene (CELG) is best known for Revlimid, its blood-cancer treatment. Do you like its other products?Demain: You're right, Revlimid is its workhorse and continues to grow due to longer treatment duration and finding new patients. But what do they do after Revlimid goes off-patent in 2026?The outlook for three other Celgene products — Pomalyst, Otezla and Abraxane — is constructive. And we're excited about its pipeline of new (treatments). Also, they've done business development deals with cash from Revlimid to build emerging franchises in gastroenterology and immunology, and inflammation and immunology. Those things should make the 2026 patent cliff for Revlimid a manageable event.IBD'S TAKE: Celgene is the No. 1 ranked stock in IBD's Medical-Biomed/Biotech industry group, which is ranked a very strong No. 4 among 197 groups. Celgene earns its top-dog status thanks to such traits as a best-possible 99 Composite Rating from IBD and an annual pretax margin of 50.4, which is the highest it's been in at least nine years. Compare its other technical and fundamental strengths to its rivals' at IBD's easy-to-use Stock Checkup tool.IBD: Microchip Technology's earnings per share growth has accelerated for six quarters in a row. Does your thesis revolve around the fact that their chips are used in a variety of products?Demain: The majority of their revenue is from microcontrollers, which are very simple computers that can go into all sorts of devices from airplanes to microwave ovens to kids' toys. That has great growth dynamics, which is a function of the growth of the Internet of Things. That's the company's sustainable growth.That business has a very fragmented customer base. You're not just selling a ton of chips to one customer like Apple (AAPL). You're selling to thousands of end markets. That's their competitive advantage.As for a good management team, the company is led by Steve Sanghi. We have high regard for his value creation. The company recently acquired Atmel, which was a large microcontroller competitor. It had good assets, but was poorly managed. Sanghi has improved operating margins and driven strong earnings growth. And valuation is not that demanding at about 15 times forward earnings.IBD: How does SS&C Technologies (SSNC) illustrate your investment approach?Demain: This is another example of sustainable growth plus competitive advantage plus strong management. SS&C provides back-office services for financial companies. As asset management matures, more companies want to focus on their core competencies. Rather than run back offices in-house, they look to outsource. And once they are embedded with a customer, other departments at the customer may outsource to them as well.SS&C is run by Bill Stone, who has a proven record of value creation. And their valuation is reasonable.IBD: Global Payments' earnings per share growth has sped up. Why?Demain: Think of Visa (V) and Mastercard (MA) as electronic payment highways. Global Payments is the on- and offramp. They have relationships with merchants who accept credit card terminals. If you run a restaurant, for example, Global gives you software that not only accepts credit cards but also helps you run your restaurant. And Global has benefited from consolidation.IBD: What makes Heico (HEIA), which designs and repairs parts for aircraft and engines, attractive to you?Demain: Only certain approved suppliers can sell parts to airlines. Planes are in service for 25, 30 years, and need servicing. But only a relatively small number of companies have parts-manufacturing approval (PMA) from the Federal Aviation Administration and the European (regulatory) body. The FAA has (limited resources) and can only approve so many parts per year. Heico has the best position in the PMA market. They earn healthy margins.Also, the Mendelson family owns a large percentage of the company. It's most of their liquid net worth, so they care a lot about creating shareholder value, so we like to partner with them.IBD: What's driven the share-price uptrend by contact-lens developer Cooper (COO)?Demain: We like their sustainable growth. Contact lens are a growing category as contacts get more comfortable. They also benefit from international growth.There are only four players: Bausch & Lomb, Johnson & Johnson (JNJ), Alcon and Cooper. Once a consumer picks one, they usually stick with it and won't change because of a small price difference.IBD: Why is index operator MSCI attractive?Demain: The way to think about them is that they benefit from the growth of ETFs. An active manager like Janus Henderson pays a fixed fee for access to a benchmark operator. For MSCI, when a fee dollar moves from an active to a passive fund, that dollar becomes more profitable.And once you are a standard index, it is hard (for users) to change.IBD: By the way, any plans to reopen Enterprise Fund to all investors?Demain: No, we are managing $18 billion (including money in Aspen Enterprise and in separately managed accounts using Enterprise's strategy). It makes us one of the larger midcap strategies. Our first priority is working on behalf of existing clients. They think being closed is in their best interests and that's why we've done this.RELATED:Winning Mutual Fund Focuses On Leading Stocks Like Autohome, MarketAxess7 Steps For Millennials Who Want To Become Rich Retirees

Amazon.com (AMZN) does not pose a major threat to credit card networks such as Visa (V), says Goldman Sachs in a digital payments industry report.XBut China's Alibaba Group (BABA) and Tencent (TCEHY) could expand their products overseas to take on U.S. players in the digital pay market, the Wall Street broker said in a report issued Friday."After several unsuccessful attempts, Amazon is seeing more traction with Amazon Payments, which allows third-party merchants to improve checkout rates by letting shoppers pay with their Amazon account," Goldman said in its report. "We think Amazon can substantially expand its reach by signing new merchants. However, we do not see Amazon as an imminent threat to PayPal or the card networks.""The card networks face real threats from China and elsewhere, and will need to invest and partner aggressively (Apple (AAPL), Square, Klarna) to ensure that faster payments stay on their rails," the brokerage went on to say.Goldman Sachs says companies will be fighting over a $200 billion market.PayPal Holdings (PYPL), privately-held Stripe and Square (SQ) will be among the online payment industry's gainers, says Goldman Sachs. It forecasts more acquisitions among old-guard "merchant acquirers" that process payments. Those include Global Payments (GPN), Vantive (VNTV), First Data (FDC), Total System Services (TSYS) and major banks.IBD'S TAKE:  Amazon and Alibaba are on IBD's Leaderboard, which follows top stocks from their work on forming bases, through their breakouts, to their post-breakout action, up to the point where they start topping. PayPal is ranked No. 25 in the IBD 50 roster of fast-growing companies."We believe traditional merchant acquirers will lose online payments share to acquirers like PayPal, Adyen, Stripe, and Wirecard who have more advanced technology solutions and who serve more online-first merchants," said the report. "We believe merchant acquirers will continue consolidating in order to mitigate pricing pressure and sustain stock multiples."Goldman Sachs is upbeat about PayPal, saying "We think investors often see PayPal's market simply as e-commerce, but we think PayPal is positioned to seed growth in new markets.""We see $28 trillion in online spending growing to $51 trillion over 10 years, driving $200 billion in new payments fee revenue," the report said.RELATED:Is The Holy Grail Of Digital Payments Just One Click Away?These 4 Top Stocks Are Soaring Into Buy Zones On EarningsArista Networks Smashes Estimates, Stock Soars After Hours
