Investors let some of the air out of Square (SQ) shares despite an earnings beat, as the electronic payment processor gave back nearly 5% of its value Thursday.XShares of Square sank 4.7% to 25.21 on the stock market today. Square had reported a second-quarter loss of 4 cents a share after the close Wednesday but that was ahead of analyst estimates calling for a loss of 5 cents a share. Revenue was up 26% to $552 million, ahead of the $536.3 million consensus view.In recent weeks, Square shares had doubled from where they were at the beginning of 2017 and shot up from around 18 to 27 between May and July. Shares still were above the 50-day moving average despite Thursday's tumble."In short, the business is clearly performing admirably," Canaccord Genuity analyst Michael Graham said in a note to clients. "That said, while we have missed the stock's run since last fall, we are nervous about not enough near-term profit support for the valuation and continue to wait for the stock's inherent volatility to provide an opportunity to become more constructive."Paul Condra from Credit Suisse Research said there is concern over a $2.7 million write-off of debt reported in the results."While the write-off is a poignant reminder that (Square) is indeed (partly) a lending business, we think it unlikely to be indicative of worsening credit trends and we believe the overall growth remains the main attraction," Condra wrote in his note to clients Thursday.IBD'S TAKE: With a Composite Rating of 97, Square ranks fifth among companies in the Finance-Credit Card Payment Group. The sector is led by Global Payments (GPN), which has the highest-possible rating of 99.Square reported a second-quarter loss of 4 cents a share, narrowing its loss from a year ago, with revenue rising 26% to $552 million, topping consensus estimates. A year earlier, Square lost 8 cents a share on sales of $438.5 million. Analysts expected Square to report a loss of 5 cents a share on sales of $536.3 million for the period ended June 30.On an adjusted basis, Square earned 7 cents vs. 2 cents in the year-earlier period. Square raised its full-year profit outlook to 22 cents on an adjusted basis, up from 18 cents at its midpoint of guidance. Square bumped its revenue forecast to $2.15 billion from $2.14 billion.San Francisco-based Square makes credit-card readers that plug into mobile phones and tablets. While Square's primary customers are small businesses, it's attracting bigger customers, analysts say. Square has expanded into providing financing and bank loans to small businesses.RELATED:Can Square Deliver A 'Wow' Quarter Amid High Earnings Expectations?

Total System Services (TSS) saw an improvement in its IBD SmartSelect Composite Rating Monday, from 94 to 96.The upgrade means the stock currently tops 96% of all other stocks in terms of key performance metrics and technical strength. The top-performing stocks tend to have a 95 or better grade as they launch a significant move.Total System Services is now out of buy range after breaking out from a 55.58 buy point in a flat base.The stock earns a 96 EPS Rating, which means its recent quarterly and annual earnings growth tops 96% of all stocks.Its Accumulation/Distribution Rating of B- shows moderate buying by institutional investors over the last 13 weeks.In Q1, the company reported 24% EPS growth. Revenue growth increased 60%, up from 58% in the prior report. That marks one quarter of increasing revenue increases.Total System Services earns the No. 3 rank among its peers in the Finance-Card/Payment Processing industry group. Global Payments (GPN) is the top-ranked stock within the group.RELATED:Which Companies Are Now Outperforming 95% Of All Stocks?

Fidelity National Information Services (FIS)and PayPal Holdings (PYPL) could figure in as buyers during the next round of mergers in the payment processing industry, says one analyst.XStifel analyst John Davis says Fidelity could acquire Total System Services (TSS) while PayPal looms as a buyer of Netherlands-based Adyen, though other companies could jump in."We believe a bidding war could break out for private European e-commerce merchant acquirer Adyen next year," said Davis in a report. "While we expect PayPal to be the ultimate acquirer given its significant funding advantage, we wouldn't completely count out Global Payments (GPN) or someone out of left field (like Google-owned Alphabet (GOOGL) or Amazon.com (AMZN))."Vantiv on July 5 agreed to buy British payment processing company Worldpay Group in a stock-and-cash deal worth about $10 billion. That deal has sparked more merger speculation. French payments specialist Ingenico last week agreed to buy Stockholm-based rival Bambora from Nordic Capital for $1.5 billion."We think the deal that makes the most sense would be (Fidelity) acquiring Total System Services given the significant potential accretion coupled with the undeniable strategic and cultural fit," said Davis in the report. "We believe strategically it is a home run as it would give (Fidelity) significant scale in issuer credit processing as well as afford the company entrance into the faster growing, higher multiple merchant acquiring business."IBD'S TAKE: PayPal stock is up 48% in 2017 and is extended following the run-up. Global Payments, Total System Services and Square all have a Composite Rating, a CAN SLIM investing metric, in the high 90s out of a possible 99. Learn more bout the group at IBD Stock Checkup.Since it was spun off from eBay (EBAY) in 2015, PayPal has evolved from a payment button to a broad payments service provider, while expanding from online checkout to mobile payments.Loop Capital recently speculated that PayPal could target Square (SQ). San Francisco-based Square makes credit-card readers that plug into mobile phones and tablets. While Square's primary customers are small businesses, it's attracting bigger customers, analysts say.Fidelity stock ticked up 0.1% to close at 90.12 on the stock market today. PayPal stock was down 0.2% to finish at 58.58. Shares in Square dipped 0.4% to 26.75. Total System Services climbed 1.4% to 62.40.RELATED:These 5 Top Stocks In IBD's No. 1 Group Are In Bases, Near Buy ZonesBiotechs On A Hot Streak, And Could Be 'Cooking With Gas'

The Nasdaq composite is in a rough patch, but hit a record high just a month ago. The S&P 500 index is about 1% from a record high. So finding leading stocks in proper bases is hard. But a quartet of highly rated payment stocks: Visa (V), Mastercard (MA), PayPal (PYPL) and Square (SQ) have just formed short flat bases and are within 5% of potential buy points. PayPal was flirting with a buy point Monday morning.XSeveral, notably Visa, Mastercard and PayPal, are part-time partners, part-time rivals. And Apple (AAPL) remains a looming threat for payments generally, but PayPal's Venmo in particular.PayPal has formed a flat base with a 55.24 buy point. On a daily chart, PayPal has only been consolidating since June 9, just four weeks ago. But it's five weeks on a weekly chart, so it meets the minimum requirement for a flat base.PayPal didn't come near its 50-day line in recent weeks, and its relative strength line is near record highs, signaling its outperformance vs. the S&P 500. PayPal closed Friday at 53.97.PayPal rose 1.8% to 54.96 on the stock market today amid positive comments from analysts. PayPal hit 55.42 intraday, briefly topping that entry.The mobile payments specialist reached deals with Visa and Mastercard last year, giving consumers more choice and giving investors another reason to buy. PayPal also runs Venmo, a peer-to-peer mobile payments and transfer service. Venmo transactions more than doubled in Q1 vs. a year earlier to $6.8 billion.Apple (AAPL) introduced its own peer-to-peer service, while Visa, Mastercard have teamed up with many banks on another such service, Zelle. Apple's peer-to-peer offering in particular has been called a potential "Venmo killer," but PayPal CEO Dan Schulman said last month that Apple won't have "end-to-end" services.RELATED:PayPal Worries Over Apple Overblown, New Deals Help: AnalystVisa, a Dow Jones industrial average component, has been consolidating for about five weeks (definitely five weeks on a weekly chart), with a potential buy point of 96.70. Visa dipped below its 50-day moving average last week, but rose back above that line on Friday, closing at 93.92. Visa rose 1.25% to 95.09 Monday.IBD'S TAKE: PayPal is rated No. 1 in IBD's Finance-Credit Card/Payment Processor group. To find the other leaders in the group and how they all measure up vs. objective criteria, go to IBD Stock Checkup.Visa and Mastercard don't hold credit balances, so don't benefit from rising interest rates like American Express (AXP) and other card firms. They make money on processing fees on merchants and card-issuing banks.Visa's takeover of Visa Europe last year has boosted growth, while Visa also recently announced a stake in big Swedish fintech startup Klarna.RELATED:Visa Invests In Hot Tech Unicorn With This Unique Twist On PaymentsMastercard, like archrival Visa, also has been consolidating since June 5. Unlike its archrival, Mastercard tested but did not undercut its 50-day line last week, rising 1.4% on Friday to 122.20. Mastercard has a buy point of 126.29. Shares climbed 0.5% to 122.76 on Monday.Square makes credit-card readers that plug into mobile phones and tablets. It mostly serves smaller businesses, but has been getting larger customers. It's also been expanding into providing credit to small firms.Square has a short flat base with a 25.07 buy point, never really approaching its 50-day line. Square climbed 1.4% to 23.93 Monday.American Express, at 84.35, is still in buy range from an 82.10 entry. American Express is a Dow component.Alliance Data Systems (ADS), which handles credit card businesses for many retailers, has a cup-with-handle pattern with a 265.54 buy point. Alliance Data Systems closed Monday at 256.19.Vantiv (VNTV), which last week bested JPMorgan Chase (JPM) in pursuit of U.K. payments firm WorldPay with a $10 billion deal, retook its 200-day moving average on Friday. It rose 1.55% to 62.07 on Monday, nearing its 50-day line. Vantiv is in a flat base going back to Feb. 27, with a potential buy point of 66.34.Global Payments (GPN) has a short flat base with a potential buy point of 93.62. Global Payments fell 0.4% to 88.63 on Monday, just below its 50-day.

Analysts upgraded Baidu (BIDU), raised price targets for Global Payments (GPN) and Square (SQ), and downgraded T-Mobile U.S. (TMUS). Loop Capital initiated coverage on fintech companies Q2 Holdings (IBD), PayPal (PYPL) and Green Dot (GDOT).Stifel raised its rating on the Chinese internet search and advertising company to buy from hold, lifting its target for Baidu to 220 from 200.On Monday, JPMorgan Chase raised its rating on Baidu to neutral from underperform, while lifting its price target to 190 from 159. Despite the better outlook, JPMorgan expressed a cautious outlook on Baidu because of competition from Weibo (WB) and lack of clarity of its strategy for profiting from video.Baidu rose 1.8% to close at 180.31 on the stock market today.MoffettNathanson downgraded the wireless carrier to neutral from buy. The research firm last month warned bullish investors that approval of an acquisition by Sprint (S) might not be a sure thing because of financial hurdles and the possibility of antitrust concerns in the incoming Trump administration.T-Mobile shares jumped 3.7% to finish trading at 58.74.Stifel boosted its price target on Global Payments to 92 from 85, keeping a buy rating on the electronic payment transaction processor.On Monday, Global Payments topped earnings and revenue estimates, raised guidance and announced a share buyback.The stock fell 2.4% to 77.88 after surging 7.2% on Monday to 79.79, just below a buy point above 79.93.Loop Capital started coverage on a host of financial technology companies. Square's (SQ) opening to sell specialized software to small merchants is bigger than streetside estimates, says Pacific Crest Securities, which hiked its price target on the payment processor.Square stock ended the day down 1%, to 14.91, on the stock market today. Shares in San Francisco-based Square have gained 12% in 2017, having climbed in every trading session this year. Square stock has formed a cup-with-handle chart pattern.Square still is best known for its credit card readers that plug onto mobile phones and tablets, a boon for many smaller companies. But Square also has expanded into providing financing for small businesses, and its software helps with invoices, email marketing, sales analytics and more.Square's "'semi-specialized' small- and medium-size software opportunity is underappreciated," said Josh Beck, a Pacific Crest analyst who upped his price target to 17 from 15. Barclays also raised its price target on Square to 17 from 15 on Tuesday.IBD'S TAKE: Netflix and Broadcom, and nontechs such as Nucor, Burlington Stores and Martin Marietta, are among stocks on IBD's Leaderboard. Leaderboard follows top stocks from their work on forming bases, through their breakouts, to their post-breakout action, up to the point where they start topping."The SMB software market is the most fragmented with Vantive (VNTV), Total System Services (TSS) and Global Payments (GPN) as the leaders; First Data (FDC) is a relatively new entrant. The national category is dominated by the likes of NCR and Micros. Square's predominant segment, micro-merchant, is relatively underserved, in our view, which creates opportunity for SQ to compete."Square went public at $9 per share in November 2015, but within three months it was trading just above 8, its all-time low. The payments field has become crowded, but Square has been striving to carve out its niche."Net-net, we see the opportunity for $5 million to $50 million of a high-margin revenue opportunity," Beck said in the report. "We are factoring in some degree of success with 'semi-specialized' software of about $10 million."Square in November hiked its guidance and reported a narrower-than-expected third-quarter loss as revenue topped views.RELATED:Square Stock Gains On Apple Pay Mobile PartnershipSquare Upgraded On Expected 'Positive Fundamental Surprises'Square Q3 Tops, Hikes Outlook On Momentum With Larger Merchants

Stocks made a mixed start Monday as the market heads into a week of heavy commentary from Federal Reserve officials and of cabinet nominees facing Senate appointment hearings.Both the Nasdaq and the Nasdaq 100 rose a fraction, but the Dow Jones industrials slipped 0.2% and the S&P 500 scraped out narrow losses in opening trade. Small caps were particularly weak, with the Russell 2000 sinking 0.5%.Markets start the week on reasonably strong footing, with the Nasdaq up 2.6%, the S&P 500 holding a 1.7% gain and Dow industrials ahead 1% so far in January, all at or near new highs and working on a third straight monthly advance.  Markets will have an eye on Washington, where a Republican-controlled Senate will give some sense of its capability to move on matters of importance as it works to confirm the first of the Trump administration's Cabinet nominees.Despite the overall flat premarket tone, leading stocks Apple (AAPL), Alphabet (GOOGL), Netflix (NFLX) and Nvidia (NVDA)  all edged higher in early trade.Apple rose 0.8% to 118.85, surpassing a 118.12 cup-with-handle entry. Watch to see how the volume fares in the first full hour of trade.Apple trades on average 32 million shares a day, or roughly 4.9 million shares each hour.On Sept. 14 last year, Apple cleared a 110.33 buy point within a long bottoming base pattern, then rallied nearly 8% before pulling back to form its latest cup base.American Express (AXP) rolled up a 0.4% gain. The Dow Jones 30 component briefly topped a three-weeks tight buy point of 75.83 last week.Exact Sciences (EXAS) leapt 19% after hoisting its fourth-quarter revenue guidance to above consensus views. The maker of molecular-level cancer screening diagnostics ended Friday back above its 10-week moving average, after rising 13% for the week.Global Payments (GPN) gapped up more than 6%. The credit card and payment processing outfit reported a solid fiscal second-quarter sales and earnings beat, raised its full-year guidance and announced a $300 million share-buyback initiative. Global Payments gained 7% last week, retaking its 40-week moving average in a shallow consolidation.China-based online retailer JD.com (JD) popped nearly 2% higher following an upgrade to overweight, from neutral, by J.P. Morgan. The report also lifted the stock's price target to 39 from 32.Urban Outfitters (URBN) shed 2%, paring its early tumble, after announcing mixed same-store sales among its various brands. Overall sales rose a weaker-then-expected 1.5% in November and December.Oil and gas drilling contractor Transocean (RIG) sank almost 4%. Bank of America cut the stock's rating to underperform, from neutral, and gave it a price target of 13.The economic calendar is thin on the stock market today, with only the Federal Reserve reporting November consumer credit data at 3 p.m. ET.But the Fed also launches into a busy week of commentary from officials, beginning with Boston Federal Reserve Bank President Eric Rosengren speaking to the Connecticut Business & Industry Association in Hartford, at 9 a.m. ET. Dennis Lockhart, President of the Atlanta Federal Reserve Bank who is set to retire Feb. 28, speaks at 12:40 p.m. ET.Oil prices slipped more than 2%, leaving West Texas Intermediate at $52.82 a barrel. Gold climbed 0.7% to $1,181 an ounce. The dollar eased from its recent gains. Rising bonds trimmed 5 basis points from the 10-year yield, to 2.37%.Overseas markets were mixed, with China's benchmarks closing higher ahead Tuesday's release of consumer price and producer price indexes. In Japan, The Tokyo Stock Exchange was closed for that country's Adults' Day holiday.London's FTSE climbed 0.3% in afternoon trade, while the CAC 40 in Paris dropped 0.8% and Frankfurt's DAX traded 0.6% lower.Banks, Delta, Auto Show, Drug Updates Lead Investing Action PlanApple Flirts With Buy, Alphabet Breaks Out, Joining NetflixStock Indexes Hit New Highs; Nasdaq Cuts Through ResistanceStock Market Today: When Did Apple Initially Break Out?

Top names in the consumer space like Dave & Buster's (PLAY) and Jack in the Box (JACK) will…

Payment processors Visa (V), MasterCard (MA) and PayPal (PYPL) sold off sharply on Monday, breaking key technical levels.Visa shares fell 4.3% to 78.38 on Monday, losing sight of a tight consolidation in recent weeks near the 50-day line. That also undercuts an earlier buy point of 81.83. Visa did manage to close just above its 200-day moving average after falling below that support level intraday.MasterCard pulled back 3.3% to 101.14 on Monday, falling in heavy volume below its 50-day line. The stock is in danger of a round trip from a late September breakout, but for now is still above the 100.10 buy point.Visa and MasterCard rose modestly before the opening bell on the stock market today.PayPal, which recently announced alliances with Visa and MasterCard, sank 3.2% to 38.81 on Monday, closing just above the 200-day line after undercutting it intraday. PayPal broke out of a consolidation on Oct. 21, a day after reporting quarterly results, hitting a new high. But shares have been retreating since then, undercutting the pivot point earlier this month and closing below the 50-day line on Friday.PayPal was flat before Tuesday's opening bell.Global Payments (GPN) and Vantiv (VNTV) also have retreated.It's unclear what it is hurting Visa, MasterCard and PayPal. They make their money from transaction fees, letting card-issuing banks such as JPMorgan Chase (JPM) and Bank of America (BAC) get the risk and reward from customers' balances. With the yield curve steepening sharply in recent weeks and especially since Donald Trump became president-elect, card interest rates may rise. Bank stocks are soaring on widening yield spreads generally.IBD'S TAKE: While Visa and MasterCard slump, investors continue to rush into bank stocks. They're mostly extended from proper buy points, but you should pay close attention to this new leading group for entry points down the road.That could be why American Express (AXP), Capital One Financial (COF) and Discover Financial (DFS) are soaring. All three carry customers' balances. American Express rose 2.7% Monday to its best levels since November 2015. Capital One jumped 3.4% to its highest since July 2015. Discover Financial advanced 3.3%, hitting an all-time high intraday.Jefferies analysts said Tuesday that the sell-off in some payment stocks is unwarranted."Major payments stocks including V, MA, PYPL, GPN and VNTV are off 5-10% in the four trading sessions since Election Day. We don't believe this is because of fundamental concerns on these stocks, but rather because of investor rotation into core Financials which have significantly lagged the payments stocks for years, but are now expected to benefit from rate and regulatory tailwinds under the Trump Administration."Jefferies added that financial deregulation could repeal the Durbin limit on interchange fees and rein in the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau. "If Trump's general plans for deregulating the financial services industry ends up including a repeal of the Durbin Amendment and a less-powerful CFPB, this should generally be a tailwind for the Payments industry, though impacts to PYPL/SQ/merchant acquirers may be less clear."

The stock market extended gains Wednesday as Wall Street took in more economic data, another round of earnings reports and a big jump in oil prices.The Nasdaq composite and Dow Jones industrial average climbed 0.7% while the S&P 500 advanced 0.5%.In economic news, private employers added 154,000 jobs in September, below expectations of 170,000, according to the latest data from ADP. The data come ahead of Friday's jobs reported where economist expect nonfarm payrolls to rise 168,000. But ISM's nonmanufacturing index surged to an 11-month high in September.WTI crude oil futures for November delivery rose nearly 2% to $49.69 a barrel. The Energy Information Administration reported that U.S. inventories fell for a fifth straight week.In the stock market today, Acacia Communications (ACIA) soared 11.5% to 113.77 after finding support at its 50-day moving average Tuesday. The fiber-optic networking technology firm was showcased in Leaderboard in mid-June and re-entered the Leaders list of premium-quality growth stocks on Tuesday.Global Payments (GPN) added just over 1% to 77.66 after reporting strong earnings before the open. It's near the top of a flat base with an 80.03 buy point. Demand for shares had been sluggish in recent weeks as evidenced by an up/down volume ratio of 1.8 and Accumulation/Distribution Rating of D-.IBD'S TAKE: Global Payments' industry group ranks in the bottom half of IBD's 197 industry group rankings, but a couple of other names in the group continue to act well. See who they are with IBD Stock Checkup.Meanwhile, strong earnings from Constellation Brands (STZ) fueled a breakout for the stock. Shares rose 2.5% to 170.02. The stock cleared a flat-base entry of 168.78.A couple of other earnings reports made early headlines. Micron Technology (MU) rose 1.5% after initial selling off. A quarterly loss of 5 cents a share handily beat expectations but sales fell 11% to just over $3.2 billion. Headed into this week, Micron showed 13 straight weekly price gains.LED lighting expert Acuity Brands (AYI) slumped 4% -- but rebounded from an intraday tumble below its long-term 200-day moving average -- despite reporting its third straight quarter of 20%+ earnings and sales growth.Inside the IBD 50, Broadcom (AVGO) got a lift after Bernstein initiated coverage with an outperform rating and price target of 215. Shares rose nearly 3% to 174. Stocks opened higher Wednesday as oil prices climbed and investors braced for a heavy slate of economic news.The Dow industrials rose 0.5% and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq climbed 0.4%.Overseas markets were mixed, with Europe's leading benchmarks down about a half percent in afternoon trade. In Japan, Tokyo's Nikkei 225 ended its session with a 0.5% gain. In China, the Hong Kong Hang Seng Index rose 0.4%.Leaderboard stock Acacia Communications (ACIA) spiked 8.5% at the starting bell. The maker of fiber-optic networking gear hiked its third-quarter earnings outlook for a second time in the past several days. The stock ended Tuesday in a buy zone as it rebounded from support at its 10-week moving average.Global Payments (GPN) rose 1% in early action. The payment processor reported its fiscal first-quarter sales and earnings narrowly topped analyst consensus views. Management raised its full-year EPS and revenue guidance in line with expectations.Constellation Brands (STZ) rose 3% after beating second-quarter forecasts. Analysts have named Google parent Alphabet (GOOGL), Facebook (FB) and Salesforce.com (CRM) as possible suitors. Oil traded up nearly 2% early Wednesday, following weekly data from the American Petroleum Institute showing U.S. oil inventories declined by 7.6 million barrels in the week ended Sept. 30, a fifth straight weekly decline. Futures for the West Texas Intermediate benchmark traded above $49 per barrel. Europe's Brent benchmark traded near $52.Comments from Federal Reserve officials will also be on investors radar. Minneapolis Federal Reserve Bank President Neel Kashkari speaks at 9:30 a.m. ET. Richmond Fed President Jeffrey Lacker speaks at 1 p.m. ET.RELATED:Constellations Brands, Global Payments Up On Earnings

Both domestic and international stock ETFs spiked Thursday, as the hotly debated Brexit referendum got under way. The vote, whose outcome is expected shortly, is still considered too close to call.Financial stocks outpaced S&P 500 sectors ahead of the release of the first batch of results from the Federal Reserve's annual stress tests. Those exams assess banks' ability to withstand shocks to the market and their finances.SPDR S&P Regional Banking (KRE) and SPDR S&P Bank (KBE) each jabbed about 3% higher. Both posted their best days in more than a month.Financial Select Sector SPDR (XLF), which holds a broadly diversified basket of financial stocks, added 2.1%.The banking sector has been hard hit by the uncertainty about the Fed's next rate move and worries about Britons' decision on whether to leave the European Union -- the "Brexit," as it has come to be known. Many investors fear that a vote to leave the 28-member bloc would cause financial chaos in the region and beyond.Financial services are the poorest-performing sector year to date, down 5% through June 22. They're also the worst performers month to date, down 2%.But banks got a dose of good news after the market close. They came off looking in good capital shape in the Fed's annual tests.On the Dow Jones industrial average, Visa (V) added about 1% Thursday.On the elite IBD 50 list, financial companies Global Payments (GPN), Equifax (EFX), Lifelock (LOCK) and TransUnion (TRU) all scored gains.European stock exchange traded funds were buoyed by reports that some opinion polls taken before the Brexit vote favored remaining in the EU bloc.IShares MSCI United Kingdom (EWU) punched up 2.7%.IShares MSCI Eurozone (EZU) swept up 3.5%.IShares MSCI Europe Financials (EUFN) jabbed 4.5% higher to its highest level since June 9.European banks trading in the U.S. pushed higher, including Deutsche Bank (DB), Credit Suisse (CS), Barclays (BCS), Royal Bank of Scotland (RBS) and Lloyds Banking Group (LYG).Gold's woes continued, meanwhile. The precious metal stands to gain from a "leave" vote in the Brexit referendum, which would boost safe-haven demand.SPDR Gold Shares (GLD) nicked a 0.7% loss. GLD is trading near a two-week low and is 4% below its June 16 high.Here's a look at how major exchange traded funds, tracking various asset classes, performed today, with Relative Price Strength (RS) ratings:SPDR S&P 500 (SPY), +1.3%, RS 59PowerShares QQQ (QQQ), +1.4%, RS 46SPDR Dow Jones Industrial Average (DIA), +1.3%, RS 59IShares Core S&P Mid-Cap (IJH), +1.9%, RS 66IShares Russell 2000 (IWM), +1.9%, RS 55IShares MSCI EAFE (EFA), +2.8%, RS 41Vanguard FTSE Emerging Markets (VWO), +2.5%, RS 50SPDR Gold Shares (GLD), -0.7%, RS 72United States Oil (USO), +2.0%, RS 32IShares Core U.S. Aggregate Bond (AGG), -0.2%, RS 50PowerShares DB U.S.$ Bullish (UUP), -0.5%, RS 30IPath S&P 500 VIX Short-Term Futures (VXX), -9.7%, RS 6

Stock futures pointed to a strong open Tuesday amid strength in most overseas markets. Nasdaq 100 futures rallied 17 points vs. fair value, and S&P 500 futures climbed 6 points. Futures on the Dow Jones industrial average jumped 64 points.
Stocks reversed higher Monday to solid gains, but volume was lower.
Equity markets overseas were mostly higher, with European bourses leading the charge. France's CAC-40 bolted 2.3% and Germany's DAX rallied 1.9%. Meanwhile, London's FTSE 100 gained 1.7%.
In Asia, Hong Kong's Hang Seng climbed about 1.2% and Japan's Nikkei gained 1.2%. But the Shanghai composite was fractionally lower.
After gaining 2.5% Monday on rising tensions from Friday's terrorist attacks in Paris, crude oil pulled back. December crude lost 60 cents to $41.14 a barrel.
On the economic front, consumer prices rose 0.2% in October. That was the the first gain in three months and matched views.
Data on industrial production and the NAHB housing market index will be out at 9:15 a.m. ET and 10 a.m. ET, respectively. Fed Governors Jerome Powell and Daniel Tarullo will be speaking later today.

In stocks, Home Depot (HD) rallied 3% in premarket trading in the stock market today after beating views. The home improvement retailer posted Q3 earnings of $1.35 a share on sales of $21.8 billion. Views were for EPS of $1.32 on revenue of $21.76 billion. It also pegged full-year earnings at $5.36 a share or a nickel above views.
Rival Lowe's (LOW) was also up 3% in premarket trading. It reports quarterly results Wednesday.

Wal-Mart (WMT) rose 2% in the premarket despite posting mixed quarterly results. The world's biggest retailer reported fiscal Q3 earnings of $1.03 a share. But excluding a gain from leases, earnings were 99 cents a share. Sales came in at $117.4 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had expected EPS of 98 cents on revenue of $117.79 billion.

Fitbit (FIT) gained more than 2% in premarket activity after being upgraded to buy from neutral at Bank Of America/Merrill Lynch. Shares of the maker of fitness trackers bounced back Monday after hitting a record low Friday.

Dick's Sporting Goods (DKS) plunged 15% in premarket trade following disappointing earnings for Q3 and a weak outlook. The retailer posted adjusted earnings of 45 cents a share on revenue of $1.64 billion. Views were for EPS of 47 cents on sales of $1.64 billion. The retailer guided Q4 earnings at $1.10 to $1.25 a share vs. views for $1.43. On Monday, shares fell to their lowest levels since January 2012.

Falling fuel prices are great for vehicle-fleet operators but not so much for fuel-card firms that get a cut on sales when customers swipe their cards at the pump.FleetCor Technologies (FLT) is one of the biggest fuel-card companies in the U.S. And it has a sizeable international business, thanks to acquisitions of local fuel-card networks.The Norcross, Ga.-based firm generates revenue from its payments network and card processing services for commercial and government fleets.The company charges fees to fleet operators that use its various fuel cards and a usage fee to gasoline companies that take the fuel cards.FleetCor and analysts who follow the firm remain upbeat about its prospects in the face of lower fuel prices in the U.S.For one thing, FleetCor generates much of its revenue from services that have nothing to do with prices at the pump.In addition to various fees, FleetCor offers productivity tools, fraud protection and fleet-maintenance management, among other money-saving services.What's more, a wide spread between the wholesale price of fuel and the retail price offsets lower fuel prices — at least in the near-term. While wholesale prices react quickly to oil-price changes, retail prices tend to follow more slowly.Profit From Price SpreadsThe spread, for now, offsets some of the negative impact from declining gas prices, acting as a kind of hedge, analysts say.Eric Dey, FleetCor's chief financial officer, said in a post-Q3 conference call that higher fuel-spread margins lifted North American revenue by $5 million in the quarter.Analysts from Evercore ISI noted in a research report earlier this month that the average spread between wholesale and retail fuel prices in the fourth quarter grew 40% year over year.Given the wide spread and a decline in foreign exchange headwinds, Evercore raised its Q4 forecast by three cents a share, to $1.38. That's two cents above analysts' consensus of $1.36. In the year-earlier period, FleetCor earned $1.08.Barclays' analysts also don't seem too fazed by the impact of lower fuel prices on FleetCor's financial health. Barclays has an "overweight" on the stock, and it notes, "Long-term prospects outweigh short-term headwinds.""We suspect that during 2015, investors will look through the gas price and (foreign exchange) impacts and instead look at normalized growth potential," analyst Darrin Peller of Barclays wrote in late December.FleetCor shares rose 27% in 2014 but are down 8% so far this year, however.The company's "normal" growth has been impressive. Revenue over the last four years has grown 26% annually on average, while earnings have gone up 36% a year on average over that time.Numerous acquisitions have fueled some of FleetCor's growth. In Q3, the three biggest deals from 2013 — in the U.S., the U.K. and Brazil — accounted for about half of the company's revenue growth, CEO Ronald Clarke said in the last conference call.Total company revenue in the quarter jumped 31% to $295.3 million, while earnings per share rose 27% to $1.37.FleetCor has made more than 60 acquisitions since 2002. They include the recent $3.45 billion deal for Comdata, which closed in November and was its biggest buy ever.Comdata provides electronic fleet, virtual card and gift card solutions to more than 20,000 customers worldwide. Fleetcor management expects sizeable synergies, including cuts in fixed costs and cross-selling opportunities.Acquiring To GrowGoldman Sachs analysts see up to $1 billion of additional "accretive" deals this year.New acquisitions, organic growth and cost synergies from the Comdata deal "will more than offset" headwinds from weak fuel prices and negative foreign currency translations, Goldman Sachs analysts wrote after a meeting with management in mid-December.FleetCor's forecast for Q4 calls for earnings of $1.33 per share, assuming a foreign currency headwind of 5 cents. Analysts on average expect $1.36, according to a poll by Thomson Reuters.For all of 2014, FleetCor raised its EPS forecast to $5.07-$5.11 from $5.04-$5.10 previously. The company also raised its 2014 revenue forecast slightly, to $1.1-$1.11 billion.For 2015, management kept its previous guidance for EPS of $6.35 at the midpoint, despite an expected $.15-$.20 EPS headwind from unfavorable foreign exchange and lower U.S. fuel prices.The 2015 EPS guidance implies a 25% gain from FleetCor's expected EPS for 2014.The CFO noted in the call that the Comdata business — yet to be acquired then — was doing better than expected and that financing costs were lower than thought.FleetCor's revenue is almost evenly split between North America and international, with faster growing North America slightly higher at 52.9% of the mix.North America revenue in Q3 jumped 35.6% vs. the prior year to $156.3 million, with organic growth of 19%.Double-digit growth in the U.K. fueled much of the growth on the international side, which saw revenue rise 26.4% to $138.9 million.Even FleetCor's business in ailing Russia was "hanging in there," CEO Clarke said in the call. He and other executives declined an interview request.Maine-based rival WEX (WEX), formerly Wright Express, saw Q3 revenue grow 16% to $222.1 million. Earnings rose 17% to $1.56 per share, but analysts expect Q4 earnings to fall 1% from a year earlier.Its shares have fallen off sharply since late November.In IBD rankings, FleetCor is rated higher than WEX, with a Composite Rating of 93 vs. WEX's 74. The highest score possible is 99. The ratings factor in several metrics such as earnings growth and stock gains.Both stocks are in IBD's Finance-Credit Card/Payment Processing industry group, which is ranked 83 of 197 groups in performance.FleetCor is No. 3 in the group by Composite Rating, after Vantiv (VNTV) and Alliance Data Systems (ADS). Other stocks rated above 90 are Global Payments (GPN), MasterCard (MA) and Euronet Worldwide (EEFT).

For three weeks, the IBD 50 has been flat even as the major indexes have made new highs. The IBD 50 climbed 0.4% last week and has crawled up less than 0.1% so far this month. By comparison, the S&P 500 is up 2.2% and the Nasdaq 1.8% in November. Why the divergence? For answers, investors can turn to the…

The Nasdaq kicked off the week with another solid performance Monday, lifted by semiconductor and biotech stocks. Micron Technology (MU) rose 0.43 to 34.73. It's trying to break free from an 18-week consolidation that shows an all-time high of 34.85. The caveat is that if a breakout gains traction, it would be a late-stage one after a big price run…
Global Payments (GPN) boosted its full-year outlook on the strength of its first-quarter results and Ezidebit closing.
Shares of the company rose 3.7% to 71.31 in the stock market today.

The payment solutions provider raised fiscal 2015 guidance to $4.65-$4.75 earnings per share and $2.74 billion-$2.79 billion in revenue. Analysts currently expect $4.60 a share on revenue of $2.73 billion.

"We continue to expand our direct distribution globally and are enthusiastic about our agreements to acquire Ezidebit and Fidelity National Information Services' gaming business," said CEO Jeff Sloan in a release.
"Both of these transactions underscore our strategy to drive direct sales growth in attractive markets, deliver innovative products and solutions and leverage technological advantages."
The company beat earnings views by 8 cents with a per-share rise of 22% to $1.22. Revenue rose 12% to $704.9 million, topping forecasts for $675.7 million.
In mid-September, Global Payments said it was acquiring Australian payment company Ezidebit for AUD $305 million, or about USD $268 million at current exchange rates.
Earlier this week, the company announced plans to acquire the gaming business of Certegy Check Services, an FIS subsidiary. It also intends to full support e-payment service Apple (AAPL) Pay.

Stocks saw modest gains early Wednesday afternoon, one day after indexes resumed their uptrends.

A quiet session saw the S&P 500 up 0.2%, while the Dow Jones industrial average and Nasdaq rose 0.1%. Volume was mixed in the early going. NYSE volume was tracking 8% lower than Tuesday. Nasdaq volume rose 12% in the stock market today.

In economic news, the ADP National Employment Report showed private employers adding 191,000 jobs in March, pretty much in line with the consensus estimate of 193,000. The data came ahead of Friday's jobs report. Nonfarm payrolls are expected to increase by 206,000, with the unemployment rate ticking lower to 6.6%.

Among the day's gainers, Tesla Motors (TSLA) added 4%. It's back above its 10-week moving average after a brief trip below the line. This is its first visit to support after a breakout in February over 194.60.
On the IPO front, digital ad exchange operator Rubicon Project (RUBI) priced at 15 last night, at the low end of a proposed range of 15-17. It opened at 17.50 and was recently trading around 20.50.

Inside the IBD 50, Myriad Genetics (MYGN) was the top percentage gainer, soaring 13%. The maker of molecular diagnostic products said the U.S. government is paying a higher reimbursement than initially thought for its main test that that can detect genes associated with breast and ovarian cancer.
Under Armour (UA) also did well, rising nearly 3%. The Leaderboard name is successfully testing its 10-week line for the first time after a breakout in January.

June gold rallied 13.40, or 1.1%, $1,293.40 an ounce. IBD's Mining-Gold/Silver/Gems industry was one of the day's top performers, rising nearly 3%. Among institutional-quality stocks in group, Randgold Resources (GOLD) added 2%, but it's not the stuff of market leadership with a Composite Rating of 62.

Stocks were lower early Thursday afternoon as biotechs faced a fresh barrage of selling ahead of Friday's jobs report.

Selling pressure was muted in the S&P 500 and the Dow, but it was a different story on the Nasdaq. The tech-heavy index lost 1%, fueled by more weakness in biotech stocks. The S&P 500 lost 0.2% and the Dow Jones industrial average gave up 0.1%. NYSE and Nasdaq volume was tracking lower than Wednesday's pace in the stock market today.

In economic news, weekly jobless claims rose 16,000 to 326,000, slightly more than expected. The data come ahead of Friday's jobs report. Nonfarm payrolls are expected to rise 206,000, with the unemployment rate ticking lower to 6.6%. In February, the economy created 175,000 jobs.
IBD's biotech industry group fell nearly 4%. Group leaders Biogen Idec (BIIB), Regeneron (REGN) and Alexion (ALXN) fell anywhere from 3% to 4%.

Google (GOOG) was off session highs as it met with resistance at its 50-day moving average, but shares still rose 1%. A new class of Google stock came to market Thursday. The new nonvoting Class C shares will traded under symbol GOOG. Class A stock, expected to trade pretty much in lockstep with C shares, will trade under the symbol GOOGL.

Inside the IBD 50, Air Lease (AL) was trying to extend its winning streak to five sessions. Shares rose 0.3%. The company purchases and leases commercial jets to airlines around the world. The stock is near highs but extended 14% past a 33.05 buy point.

On the downside, volatile trading continued in China growth names, including Autohome (ATHM). Shares lost 6%. It's been trying to firm up at its 10-week moving average for the first time after a breakout from an IPO base, but support is in question. Shares crumbled 10% last week and the stock closed right at its 10-week line. It's slightly below the line now.

A decent open for the market was short-lived Thursday. Losses weren't bad, but stocks were near session lows with a little over one hour remaining in the session.

The Nasdaq led the way, falling 0.5%. The Dow Jones industrial average lost 0.3% and the S&P 500 gave up 0.2%. Preliminary data showed NYSE volume tracking 4% higher than Wednesday. Nasdaq volume was 1% higher.

In the stock market today, leading growth names in China were pressured. Qihoo 360 Technology (QIHU) slumped 8% and fell below its 50-day moving average. It gapped above its 50-day line Wednesday after Alibaba announced it was moving into mobile gaming distribution. Investors speculated that Alibaba might make an investment in Qihoo. Other China names under pressure Thursday included TAL Education Group (XRS), down 4%; Baidu (BIDU), down 3%; and Netease (NTES), down 2%.

The big winner was Intercept Pharmaceuticals ICPT. Shares soared 275% after the company stopped a clinical trial of a liver-disease drug because the drug already met its endpoint. Intercept isn't profitable, but boasts high-quality mutual fund sponsorship.

U.S. drug distributor McKesson (MCK) followed through after Wednesday's flat base breakout over 166.67. Shares rose 3% after the company increased its offer to buy German rival Celesio to $8.4 billion from $8.2 billion.

Elsewhere, Yandex's (YNDX) recent breakout over 41.90 gained traction. Shares rose 4.5% in strong trade after Morgan Stanley named the Russian search firm its top media pick for 2014. Yandex is a Leaderboard stock.

On the earnings front, Global Payments (GPN) soared 4%. Late Wednesday, the provider of electronic payments transaction processing services reported solid earnings with profit up 15% from a year ago. Sales growth accelerated for the second straight quarter, rising 8% to $634.1 million.

The December jobs report will be released Friday at 8:30 a.m. ET. A quiet session for stocks Monday resulted in slim pickings in the New Highs list, but a few interesting names made the cut. IBD 50 component and Sector Leader Valeant Pharmaceuticals (VRX) extended its winning streak to five sessions, rising 3.82 to 117.42. It cleared a flat-base buy point of 115.50. Volume was only 18% above average — not bad,…

Broad gains in the stock market Wednesday ushered big moves among many leading stocks and extended gains into new high territory. Payment processor Global Payments (GPN) jumped more than 5% to close at 75.68 in volume that was 70% above average. The stock broke out of a 19-week cup but is in a later-stage base. The major market averages closed at their highest levels this year as U.S. stocks followed overseas markets higher Wednesday, boosted by strong export data from China.The Nasdaq led with a 1.5% jump, while the S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial average each advanced 1%. Volume swelled on both major exchanges vs. Tuesday, according to preliminary numbers. Winners trumped losers by a 3-to-1 margin on the NYSE and the Nasdaq.In economic news, retail sales dipped 0.3% in March, more than forecasts for a 0.1% increase. Excluding automobiles, sales climbed 0.2% vs. views for a 0.4% gain. March producer prices also came in below estimates, suggesting that inflation remains in check.Top gainers in the stock market today included consumer electronics, steel and big banks. The downside was led by tobacco, meat products and gold miners. Some oil and gas plays were lower too, as West Texas intermediate crude prices slipped 1% to below $42 a barrel.JPMorgan Chase (JPM) and Goldman Sachs (GS) paced the Dow with gains of about 4% apiece. JPMorgan marked a three-month high in heavy volume after reporting better-than-expected Q1 results.Apple (AAPL) added 1.5% to extend its advance for a fourth consecutive session and closed above its 200-day moving average, a key support level, for the first time in five months. All eyes will be on Apple when it reports earnings April 25 after the close. The company is forecasting a revenue decline, which may reflect slowing iPhone demand. Analysts expect fiscal Q2 EPS to fall 14% to $2 on a 10% sales drop to $52 billion.On the IBD 50, 38 stocks advanced and 12 declined. Chinese K-12 tutoring services provider Tal Education Group (XRS) spiked 6% to a new high in above-average trade, extending its win streak to a sixth straight session. Shares are extended well past a 48.94 entry and a pullback to the 10-week line.Global Payments (GPN) surged 5% to a new high, clearing a 74.74 cup-base buy point in robust trade. Shares have been mostly higher since the payment processor beat quarterly views last week on both the top and bottom lines, and boosted its full-year earnings outlook. Global in December said it will buy rival Heartland Payment Systems (HPY).Among other IBD 50 stocks making big moves, Ellie Mae (ELLI) and LendingTree (TREE) rose 4% and 5%, respectively.Economic data on tap for Thursday include the consumer price index for March and weekly jobless claims.

Stock indexes Thursday gave back the previous session’s gains, leaving bulls with the unwelcome conviction that price gains are now more like loans than gifts. The Nasdaq skidded 1.5%, while the S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial average braked 1.2% and 1% respectively. The IBD 50 lost 1.1%. Volume rose on the Nasdaq but fell slightly on the NYSE.…

Sellers were in control from the get-go Thursday and never loosened their grip.The Nasdaq slumped 1.5%, the S&P 500 lost 1.2%, and the Dow Jones industrial average fell 1%. Volume on the Nasdaq came in slightly higher than Wednesday's level. NYSE volume was very close to Wednesday's level.The Nasdaq 100 also lost 1.5%, weighed down by weak performances for Vertex (VRTX), Alexion (ALXN) and eBay (EBAY). EBay slumped nearly 5% after ChannelAdvisor said eBay's same-store sales in March fell 0.2% after a 9.5% growth in February.At the New York Mercantile Exchange, West Texas Intermediate crude oil for May delivery gave up 49 cents, or 1.3%, to $37.26 a barrel. Gold, meanwhile, rose $13.70, or 1.1%, to $1,236.20 an ounce. SPDR Gold Shares (GLD), which tracks the price of gold, rallied 1.4%. It's on pace for another breakout try over a 120.94 buy pointOn the NYSE, declining stocks outnumbered advancers by about 4-to-1; Nasdaq decliners topped advancers by about 3-to-1.Also on the stock market today, Global Payments (GPN) added more than 1% in strong volume. It's working a solid, cup-shaped base with a 74.74 buy point, but single-digit or decelerating sales growth in recent quarters should be a yellow flag for growth investors.In earnings news, under-the-radar retailer Ollie's Bargain Outlet (OLLI) gapped up and rose 10% after reporting solid earnings late Wednesday. It recently cleared a cup-with-handle base with a 22.63 buy point.Inside the IBD 50, China-based TAL Education (XRS) was among a handful of names that closed higher. Shares rose 1%. TAL stock is seeking support at its 10-week moving average for the first time after a base breakout in mid-February.Also in the IBD 50, Facebook (FB) reversed lower but lost only 0.1% as it carves a cup-with-handle base with a 117.09 buy point. Earnings are due April 27 after the close.

Wine-and-beer giant Constellation Brands (STZ) and smart-lighting provider Acuity Brands (AYI) broke out past buy points Wednesday, while payment-processing and tech leader Global Payments (GPN) climbed closer to a buy point, after all three highly rated companies reported stellar quarterly results and bullish outlooks. Meanwhile, top-rated Ollie's Bargain Outlet (OLLI) shot up late on its strong results and guidance.The companies are cashing in on growing trends. For Constellation, it's the ever-growing interest in craft-everything that has disrupted big booze makers. For Acuity, it's the rising popularity of LED lighting and the Internet of Things. For Global Payments, it's the increasingly mobile, digital payments landscape in smaller businesses. For Ollie's Bargain Outlet, it's America's love of off-price, closeout merchandise.Constellation Brands, the parent of Mondavi wines and Corona beer, reported fourth-quarter earnings per share of $1.19, up 15% and a nickel above estimates. Sales grew 14% to $1.54 billion, topping views for $1.52 billion. Beer organic net sales rose 18% during the quarter, while wine and spirits net sales rose 4% on a constant currency basis.The company also said that it was mulling an IPO for part of its Canadian wine business and announced the $285 million acquisition of “super luxury” winemaker Prisoner Wine from Huneeus Vintners. The purchase, set to close at the end of this month, follows Constellation's announced acquisition of craft beer company Ballast Point in November.For fiscal 2017, the beverage company anticipates $6.05-$6.35 on a comparable basis and $6-$6.30 on a reported basis. The midpoint tops expectations for $6.11.Shares punctured through a cup base with a 155.78 buy point, closing up 5.9% to 160.34.Meanwhile, Acuity Brands said that its second-quarter EPS had surged 53% to $1.80, beating an outlook for $1.51. Sales climbed 26% to $777.8 million, above analyst expectations of $752 million. Sales of LED-based items jumped more than 40%, accounting for roughly 55% of total sales.The results came despite Acuity's investments in its offerings in building management, the Internet of Things and other areas. The company said that it would continue to gain from demand for better lighting and connected, energy-conscious building management in the years to come.Acuity added that it was making good progress on some of its recent acquisitions. Those purchases will expand Acuity's operations in lighting, building automation and indoor building-navigation and analytics technology, which could be used in places like malls, colleges and airports.Acuity's stock catapulted past a 222.95 buy point of a cup-with-handle base, finishing at 254.85, up 13.3%.Strong results in Europe and North America helped lift Global Payments' Q3 results. EPS rose 17% to 70 cents, above views for 67 cents. Adjusted net revenue increased 6% to $497 million, above views for $493 million. Sales rose 11% on a constant-currency basis.The firm also bumped its full-year EPS forecast to $2.93-$3.00, up from $2.90-$3.00 and surpassing consensus. The brighter outlook comes despite a tough foreign-exchange environment.The company makes a lot of its money as a card-payments-processing intermediary between businesses and financial institutions. With its acquisition of Heartland Payment Systems (HPY), it hopes to expand its payment-technology offerings for smaller businesses. Global Payments Chief Executive Officer Jeff Sloan said, "(We) look forward to closing the transaction later this month.”Global Payments gapped up 8.8% to 70.86, getting closer to a 74.74 buy point of a cup base. Heartland, meanwhile, jumped 4% to a record high.After the market close, Ollie's Bargain Outlet reported fiscal  fourth-quarter earnings of 31 cents a share excluding one-time items, beating analyst consensus by 3 cents a share, pushing  shares up late Wednesday.Sales rose 21% to $243.4 million, topping views for $239.1 million.The retail closeout chain guided sales for the current fiscal year ending Jan. 28, 2017, of $865 million to $875 million, with the midpoint below the consensus for $872.3 million. But it expects 83-85 cents EPS, vs. views for 76 cents.Ollie's stock rose 5.7% to 24 in after-hours action. Shares closed up 0.9% to 22.70 on the stock market today, retaking a 22.63 buy point. But the late stock action suggests Ollie's may move out of the buy range limit of 23.76.Elaine Low and James DeTar contributed to this articleImage provided by Shutterstock.

Card-processing and payment-technology giant Global Payments (GPN) on Wednesday spiked after strong third-quarter earnings on strength in North America and Europe despite a tough foreign-exchange environment.Heartland Payment Systems (HPY), a rival payment processor that Global Payments agreed to buy in December, surged 4% to a new high.Global Payments bumped its full-year EPS forecast to $2.93-$3.00, up from $2.90-$3.00. The new midpoint is above consensus views for $2.94, largely due to Q3's better-than-expected result.Third-quarter EPS rose 17% to 70 cents, topping expectations for 67 cents. Adjusted net revenue increased 6% to $497 million, above views for $493 million. Sales rose 11% on a constant-currency basis.Some 2 million locations across 29 countries use Global Payments' products. The company provides payment processing for merchants, serving as an intermediary between businesses and banks.Shares rose 8.8% to 70.86 on the stock market today, climbing their way through a cup base formed in December with a 74.74 buy point.That consolidation began after Global Payments announced plans to buy Heartland, potentially expanding Global's access in payment solutions for smaller businesses and in sectors as varied as education and correctional facilities. But there was some sense on the Street that Global Payments had paid too much.In its statement Wednesday, Global Payments' Chief Executive Officer Jeff Sloan said, "We are delighted with the progress we have made on the partnership with Heartland Payment Systems and look forward to closing the transaction later this month."As more people do business over phones or tablets, and e-commerce becomes the norm, the payments industry has tried to broaden its reach and become more digitally focused, often through acquisitions. Global Payments has expanded international support for Apple (AAPL) Pay, Alphabet (GOOGL) Android Pay and Samsung Pay in recent months.Total System Services (TSS), another payment processor, climbed 1.2%. Card giant Visa (V) advanced  1.6%, while MasterCard (MA) eked out a 0.4% gain.Apple rose 1.05% and Alphabet 1.25%.

A larger pile of growth stocks near highs and many more in solid bases. Others in buy range after recent breakouts. A perfect storm for growth investors, right? Yes and no. On the one hand, it’s good to see the market serving up an increasing supply of bullish technical setups. That’s typically a sign of a healthy market. But when stocks are building…
Major averages held small gains early Wednesday, one day after indexes resumed their uptrends.

The S&P 500 led the way, up 0.2%, while the Dow Jones industrial average and Nasdaq rose 0.1%. Volume was mixed in the early going. NYSE volume was tracking 12% lower than Tuesday. Nasdaq volume rose 12% in the stock market today.

In economic news, the ADP National Employment Report showed private employers adding 191,000 jobs in March, pretty much in line with the consensus estimate of 193,000. The data came ahead of Friday's jobs report. Non-farm payrolls are expected to increase by  206,000, with the unemployment rate ticking lower to 6.6%.
On the IPO front, digital ad exchange operator Rubicon Project (RUBI) priced at 15 last night, at the low end of a proposed range of 15-17. It opened at 17.50 and was recently trading around 20.

Myriad Genetics (MYGN) was the top percentage gainer in the IBD 50 Wednesday, soaring 13%. The maker of molecular diagnostic products said the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services updated its pricing for tests involving the BRCA1 and BRCA2 genes. This means more money for Myriad. Myriad cleared a buy point of 34 during the week ended February 21. It started firming at its 10-week moving average this week.
Also in the IBD 50, Rexnord (RXN) added nearly 4%. It's back above its 10-week moving average, 2% above a recent buy point of 29.39.

Autohome (ATHM) continued to firm up at its 10-week moving average for the first time after clearing a first-stage IPO base in February. Shares rose 1%. The company provides interactive content to prospective car buyers in China.

The Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 didn't move much Thursday, but it was a different story on the Nasdaq as growth stocks — biotechs in particular — took heavy hits.

With a little over one hour remaining in the session, the Nasdaq lost 1.1%, the S&P fell 0.3% and the Dow eased 0.2%. The market was trying to avoid a distribution day as NYSE and Nasdaq volume continued to track lower than Wednesday in the stock market today.

In economic news, weekly jobless claims rose 16,000 to 326,000, slightly more than expected. The data come ahead of Friday's jobs report. Nonfarm payrolls are expected to rise 206,000, with the unemployment rate ticking lower to 6.6%. In February, the economy created 175,000 jobs.
IBD's biotech industry group took another hit, falling nearly 4%. Group leaders Biogen Idec (BIIB), Regeneron (REGN) and Alexion (ALXN) dropped anywhere from 2% to 3%.
Solar stock were also weak as IBD's Energy-Solar group fell close to 4%.
China growth names under pressure Thursday included Vipshop Holdings (VIPS), down 6%; YY (YY), down 8%; Qihoo 360 (QIHU), down 6%; and SouFun (SFUN), down 7%.

Breakouts were rare, but NRG Yield (NYLD) was one. Shares rose 3%, clearing a 41.28 buy point. The company operates contracted renewable and conventional generation and thermal infrastructure assets in the U.S. It's delivered two straight quarters of triple-digit sales growth. It yields 3.3%.

Among oil and gas producers, Newfield Exploration (NFX) extended gains after a recent cup-with-handle breakout over 29.30. Shares rose 4% after UBS upgraded shares to buy from neutral. Newfield is now 12% above the buy point. Sales growth has been accelerating in recent quarters at the Woodlands, Texas-based firm.

Google (GOOG) gave back early gains and was mostly unchanged. A new class of Google stock came to market Thursday. The new, nonvoting Class C shares will trade under the ticker symbol GOOG. Class A stock, expected to trade pretty much in lockstep with C shares, will trade under the symbol GOOGL.

Stocks faded into the close Tuesday, with the Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 snapping five-session winning streaks. But volume was lower.The Nasdaq slid 1.3%, the S&P 500 lost 1.1% and the Dow slipped 0.6%. Volume in the stock market today fell 6% on the Nasdaq and 2% on the NYSE compared with Monday, according to preliminary data.Oil, mining and machinery stocks fell after China reported a 25% plunge in February exports, raising concerns about global economic growth. Crude prices fell more than 4%, erasing much of the prior day's gains.Caterpillar (CAT) led the Dow lower, sliding 4% and slicing through its 200-day moving average. The stock is trying to recover from a downtrend that began in mid-2014.In post-session trading, Blue Buffalo Pet Products (BUFF) spiked 11% after the maker of natural pet food posted its Q4 results. The stock, which debuted in July, ended the regular session down nearly 5%. It's 35% off its 52-week high.Electronic payment stocks led the IBD 50 lower during the regular session. Vantiv (VNTV) slumped 3%, sinking further below a 53.56 buy point of a cup base. It initially broke out Feb. 26, but volume was weak and the stock rolled over. Meanwhile, Global Payments (GPN) dropped more than 2%, piercing its converging 50-day and 200-day lines.Square (SQ), Vera Bradley (VRA), Express (EXPR) and Korn Ferry International (KFY) are among companies due to report quarterly results Wednesday.Economic reports scheduled for Wednesday include wholesale inventories for January and crude oil inventories for the week ended March 5.

Global Payments (GPN) is testing critical support in the stock market today.The move comes one month ahead of the payment processor's next quarterly report, which is expected to show earnings growth of 19% and a sales decline of 24%.Shares are testing support at the 50-day and 200-day lines, falling 2.2% to breach those levels in intraday trade. Global Payments' volume was tracking lighter than average.The two lines are converging, which is a bearish sign. Global Payments’ performance over the past few months has lagged, with the stock coming as much as 31% below its December high. Shares are now about 20% below a consolidation buy point.Elsewhere in the payments space, Square (SQ) will issue its quarterly results after the close on Wednesday. Analysts expect to see a per-share loss of 13 cents. Revenue is projected to jump 37%.Square is working on an IPO base with a 14.88 buy point. The stock is currently trading 21% below the pivot, down 5.7% Tuesday afternoon.PayPal (PYPL), which is on the IBD 50 list of leading stocks, is also working on an IPO base. PayPal shares are trading 9% below a potential buy point, down 1.5% in afternoon trade.Fellow IBD 50 member Vantiv (VNTV) is hovering under a 53.56 cup buy point, which it attempted to break out of late last month. Vantiv's stock fell 3.1% Tuesday, and is 5% below its recent high.Visa (V) dropped below its converging 50-day and 200-day lines on Monday, while MasterCard (MA) dropped below its downward-sloping 50-day line on Monday.Visa and Mastercard fell 1.6% and 1.5%, respectively, Tuesday afternoon.

Loading the player... A technology revolution is sweeping through the credit card and payment processing industry. And Vantiv (VNTV) is one top-rated stock cashing in on that change. The Ohio-based firm handles 18% of U.S. payment transactions and is a key driver of the so-called EMV migration -- the shift to more secure credit cards embedded with chips using technology developed…

Loading the player... You’ve certainly noticed the shift from swiping your credit card at the register to making purchases by inserting a new type of card with an embedded chip. Vantiv is one of the key players driving that trend. Known in the payment processing industry as the EMV migration, merchants are adopting the new system that enhances security by…

With Valentine's Day on Sunday, love is in the air, and if you're single, is probably poisoning it.But as couples lock down dinner reservations and gift orders, and single men cram for dates with books by Neil Strauss, here are five highly-rated IBD 50 companies that, in one way or another, could make for steamy investor relations: Facebook (FB), Global Payments (GPN), Michael Kors (KORS), Nike (NKE) and PayPal (PYPL).With oil prices diving and China's economy slowing, the prospect of a recession and credit-market contagion are on the minds of curious lovers everywhere. Let a strong company like Nike be your rock with its cash flow, solid dividend and share repurchase program, as it unlocks your passion with brand innovation.Cue the slow music and let the rose petals fall where they may as Jefferies finds the words:"Nike offers consistent cash flow and also a growth opportunity tied to continued success in China and emerging markets, and share gains for the brand and the sportswear category. While (analyst Edward Plank) likes the strong growth prospects for NKE outside of the core North America base and focus on capital returns to shareholders, he highlights Nike’s already dominant global market share in athletic footwear and competitive separation as contributing to consistent cash flow. Eddie anticipates new product innovation, driven by the 2016 Summer Olympics, will help to drive growth over the next year."In that research note, released Friday, Jefferies cited Nike as among its picks with "idiosyncratic growth and some degree of protection from a downturn."The company could also become more involved with Apple (AAPL), whose Apple Watch has fitness-tracking capabilities.Shares of Nike closed down 1.3% for the week. Apple ended virtually flat.Nothing is more attractive than confidence, and analysts praised social media giant Facebook after its Q4 results last month soundly topped estimates, and CEO Mark Zuckerberg said the company was "thriving." Facebook has grown through mobile and video ads and has broken into virtual reality through its Oculus Rift headset, with romantic implications that need not be mentioned here.But for those who will not be boldly exploring any new boundaries this weekend, Facebook at least has one feature (detailed in this press release) that allows you to reduce your exposure to your exes.Shares cleared a consolidation in the days following Facebook's report, but they fizzled afterward and are currently testing support at their 50-day line.Facebook finished 2% lower for the week.Maybe your significant other wants a new handbag. Well, Michael Kors sells lots of handbags. And their stock jumped 23.9% on Feb.2 following the release of view-topping holiday-quarter results, which were boosted luxury offerings and e-commerce.Jefferies, in a note last month, predicted a rebound in handbags' appeal, citing new spring trends and slowing shoe sales, leaving shoppers with more money potentially to buy crossbodies, mini-bags or "bag-cessories."Michael Kors shares lost 4.4% for the week, finding some love above their 200-day line after a long dry spell below it.Whatever you buy on Valentine's Day, payment processor Global Payments could help you seal the deal, indulging customers with robust support for Apple Pay and a product suite of online and brick-and-mortar payment-technology solutions across 29 countries.But no multibillion-dollar company can drift through this entropic world alone forever, especially as the payments landscape becomes more competitive with the rise of e-commerce. To that end, Global Payments in December announced the $4.3 billion acquisition of Heartland Payment Systems (HPY), allowing it to reach out to smaller and midsize businesses.Shares gained 1.9% for the week, but the stock has trended below its key 50-day and 200-day moving averages.Meanwhile, PayPal, which Jefferies also cited as a good growth stock for an uncertain time, has become a globally recognized leader in online payments, partly due to social-payments app Venmo."We see PayPal as the best positioned large-cap payments company for the current environment, with a strong hold on its core online market and options on tangential markets remittance, credit and in-store," Wedbush analyst Gil Luria said in a research note last month.Shares fell 2.2% for the week, testing support at their 50-day line.Image provided by Shutterstock.

Stock futures swung low in premarket trade Monday as techs continued to show weakness relative to the broader market. Nasdaq 100 futures slumped 79.5 points below fair market value, down about 1.9%. Dow and S&P 500 futures slipped 1.2%. In small caps, Russell 2000 futures held to a 1% decline. The U.S.  stock market today may be feeling some early…

Low gasoline prices are a boon for consumers, and economists argue the benefit will spread to spending in other parts of the economy. But low gas prices also hurt the companies behind the means to so much freer spending — credit cards. Gas purchases comprise around 10% of payment volume at Visa and MasterCard, according to Barclays analyst Darrin Peller.…

Embattled restaurant chain Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) had its price target slashed early Thursday, while Micron Technology (MU) also got a price target cut and payment processing firm Global Payments (GPN) had its price target raised following a major buyout announcement earlier this week. On an abbreviated trading day on Wall Street, Telsey Advisory Group lowered its price target on…

Global Payments (GPN) on Tuesday said it would buy Heartland Payment Systems (HPY) for $4.3 billion, creating a payment processing and technology giant that would serve 2.5 million merchants around the world and potentially expand services to many small and medium-sized businesses.Global Payments will pay $53.28 plus 0.6687 a share per Heartland Payment Systems share, equal to $101.04 as of Tuesday's close. Heartland shot up 11.8% to 95.10 in after-hours action on the stock market today. Global Payments dipped 2.3% to 69.76.The deal is expected to close in the fourth quarter of Global Payments' fiscal 2016. Global Payments said it will offer 0.6687 shares of Global Payments stock and $53.28 for each share of Heartland. Global Payments shareholders will own around 84% of the new company.Global Payments said the deal would be "mid-single digit accretive on a percentage basis" to EPS in fiscal 2017 and would be "double-digit accretive" after that. The deal is expected to produce $50 million in savings in fiscal 2017.Talks of the merger were first reported last week, pushing Heartland Payment up nearly 5% for the week and Global Payments down 1%. If a deal were approved by regulators, it would follow further consolidation in the payment processing industry. The sector has grown on the strength of e-commerce, more secure credit cards and the advent of Apple (AAPL) Pay and other mobile payments.Global Payments is a middleman between merchants and card-issuing banks such as JPMorgan Chase (JPM). Global Payments works with, not against, Apple Pay, Samsung Pay and other mobile payment options for customers.Global Payments also said its Q2 sales rose 5% to $518 million, below consensus for $526.78 million. EPS rose 15% during the quarter to 76 cents, topping by a penny.The company also kept its full-year 2016 sales guidance of $2.06 billion to $2.10 billion, below views. It expects full-year EPS guidance of $2.90-$3.00, just below the midpoint.Follow Bill Peters on Twitter @IBD_BPeters.
Stocks held solid gains in afternoon trading Wednesday after the Fed, as expected, raised interest rates by a quarter-point for the first time since June 2006.
The S&P 500 and Nasdaq each added 0.6%. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.5%. Volume on the NYSE and Nasdaq tracked lower than Tuesday's levels in the stock market today.

The market interpreted the Fed statement as dovish as Fed Chief Janet Yellen once again emphasized that the pace of tightening will be gradual. At the end of 2016, the Fed expects a fed funds rate at 1.4%, then 2.4% in 2017 and 3.3% in 2018.

At the New York Mercantile Exchange, WTI crude oil futures were trading at $35.96 a barrel, down nearly 4%. New government data showed an unexpected rise in crude inventories last week. The 10-year Treasury yield was up 3 basis points to 2.30%.
Top performers in the Nasdaq 100 included Tesla (TSLA), up nearly 4%, and Cognizant (CTSH), up nearly 3%.
In M&A news, Heartland Payment Systems (HPY) soared 11% after Global Payments (GPN) agreed to buy the payment processor for $4.3 billion. Global Payments crashed 9%.

Meanwhile, solar stocks rallied on news of a budget deal reached by House Republicans that would lift a ban on crude oil exports and extend an investment tax credit for solar firms. The bill still needs to be approved by the House and Senate. First Solar (FSLR) jumped close to 9%. Headed into Wednesday, it was having problems clearing a 59.95 buy point, but it gapped above the entry today.
In economic news, housing starts and building permits rose much more than expected in November. The data helped lift IBD's home-building group to an early 1.6% gain, but the gain faded to 0.5%.

Gains by the major indexes Thursday failed to produce many fresh breakouts. But two stocks stood out. Global Payments (GPN) found solid support at its 10-week moving average and bounced off it with power. The catalyst was a Bloomberg report that it plans to buy smaller rival Heartland Payment Systems (HPY). Global Payments rose 1.82 to close at 71.45. Volume…

Stocks extended losses midday Thursday, a day after the Federal Reserve raised interest rates for the first time in nearly a decade. The S&P 500 fell 0.8%, while the Dow Jones industrial average and the Nasdaq were each down 0.7%.
Volume was running higher on both the NYSE and the Nasdaq compared to the same time Wednesday.

Economic news was mixed, with unemployment claims falling a little less than expected in the week ended Dec. 12, while manufacturing in the mid-Atlantic region fell much more than expected in December. The Conference Board's index of leading economic indicators rose 0.4% in November, down from the prior month's 0.6% increase but ahead of analysts' forecasts.
Mining and energy stocks were hit hardest in the stock market today on declines in oil and metals prices.
Newmont Mining (NEM), a Colorado-based miner of gold and silver, lost 8%, leading the S&P 500 lower. Oil transportation stock Oneok (OKE) also dropped about 8%.

Most IBD 50 stocks were lower, led by Global Payments (GPN), which fell more than 2% in heavy volume. The stock plunged 8% on Wednesday, slicing through its 50-day line, after agreeing to buy rival credit card payments processor Heartland Payment Systems (HPY) for $4.3 billion.
Total System Services (TSS), another credit card payments processor in the IBD 50, fell 2.7% but remains well above a 48.18 buy point of a cup-with-handle base that it cleared in October.
But Chinese social media stock Weibo (WB) was a bright spot. It jumped more than 4% in heavy volume, closing in on a 20.80 buy point of a deep, cup-shaped base.

The stock boasts a rising Relative Strength line and an Accumulation/Distribution Rating of A, indicating strong demand for the shares. The stock has more than doubled since falling to a low of 8.78 on Aug. 24.Stocks extended losses midday Thursday, a day after the Federal Reserve raised interest rates for the first time in nearly a decade. Several dividend-paying stocks got upgrades from analysts early Thursday, led by Tulsa, Okla.-based natural gas gatherer and processor Oneok (OKE).Credit Suisse upgraded Oneok to outperform, with a price target of 40. Shares jumped 5.2% at the close on the stock market today to end the day at 24.66. Oneok forecast earlier this month that it would handle higher gas volumes…

Stocks pared gains at midday Wednesday amid expectations the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates later in the day. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq were each up 0.2% while the Dow Jones industrial average edged up 0.1%.
Volume on the Nasdaq and the NYSE were tracking below Tuesday's levels.
Fed policymakers are expected to raise interest rates by 25 basis points, marking the first increase since the central bank dropped rates to near zero in 2008 amid the financial crisis.
In the stock market today, drugmaker Valeant Pharmaceuticals (VRX) jumped 7% in heavy volume despite issuing a weaker-than-expected 2016 earnings forecast.

The stock jumped 16% Tuesday after announcing a distribution agreement with Walgreens Boots Alliance (WBA), which the Canada-based drugmaker said would help rebuild its business after it cut ties with Philidor Rx Services amid allegations of wrongdoing. However, Valeant's forecast for a 30% jump in 2016 profit fell short of analysts' expectations.
Solar stocks were among the day's best performers, led by First Solar (FSLR), which jumped 8% to a new high in heavy volume.

Makers of solar panels and components have gotten a lift after negotiators from the U.S. and nearly 200 other countries reached a deal last weekend to cut greenhouse gas emissions. The agreement could lead to greater investment in energy efficient solar technologies like solar.

On the downside, Global Payments (GPN) plunged 10% in heavy volume, slicing through its 50-day line, after the credit card payments processor said it would buy rival Heartland Payment Systems (HPY) for $4.3 billion.

Meanwhile, homebuiders rose after housing starts and building permits rose much more than expected in November, according to data from the Commerce Department. That sent homebuilders Pulte Group (PHM) and Toll Bros. (TOL) each up 2%, while D.R. Horton (DHI) and Lennar (LEN) both rose about 1%.Stocks pared gains at midday Wednesday amid expectations the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates later in the day.
